    https://vancouver.ca/parks-recreation-culture/queen-elizabeth-park.aspx
- **Stanley Park (Stanley Park Drive & Rose Garden area)** – Blossoms plus seawall views.  
  - Park info: https://vancouver.ca/parks-recreation-culture/stanley-park.aspx
- **Downtown & West End streets** – Notably around Burrard Station, Nicola St, and Beach Ave.
- **Vancouver Cherry Blossom Festival** – Usually early–late April; includes guided walks, bike rides, and cultural events.  
  - Official site: https://www.vcbf.ca/

---

## 2. Explore Stanley Park & the Seawall

Spring is ideal: fewer tourists than summer, but usually mild and bright.

**What to do:**
- Walk or bike the **Seawall** (10 km loop around the park).
- Visit **Totem Poles at Brockton Point**.
- Detour into the forest trails (less muddy than winter, fresher than summer).

**Bike rentals:** along Denman St near the park entrance (e.g., Spokes, Yes Cycle).

---

## 3. Visit Queen Elizabeth Park & Bloedel Conservatory

At 152 m above sea level, this is Vancouver’s highest point and a spring flower hotspot.

**Highlights:**
- **Seasonal gardens** – Rhododendrons, cherry blossoms, and manicured beds.
- **Bloedel Conservatory** – Tropical dome with exotic plants and free-flying birds; great if it’s raining.  
  - Info & tickets: https://vancouver.ca/parks-recreation-culture/bloedel-conservatory.aspx

**Park info:**  
https://vancouver.ca/parks-recreation-culture/queen-elizabeth-park.aspx

---

## 4. Wander VanDusen Botanical Garden

**Why go in spring:**
- Peak bloom for many collections.
- Less crowded than during the December Festival of Lights.

**Details & tickets:**  
https://vandusengarden.org/

---

## 5. Stroll the University of British Columbia (UBC) Area

The UBC peninsula is especially pretty in spring.

**Key spots:**
- **UBC Botanical Garden** – Forested garden with magnolias, rhodos, and a canopy walk (Greenheart TreeWalk, seasonal).  
  https://botanicalgarden.ubc.ca/
- **Nitobe Memorial Garden** – Traditional Japanese garden that’s stunning during cherry blossom season.  
  https://botanicalgarden.ubc.ca/visit/nitobe-memorial-garden/

---

Spring is shoulder season: lively but not packed like July–August.

**What to do:**
- Browse the **Public Market** for local produce, seafood, and snacks.

Full_Prompt: What are the best things to do in Vancouver in Spring? Give me sources for your answer where applicable.
Answer:
Here are some of the best things to do in Vancouver in spring (March–May), when flowers are blooming, days are longer, and crowds are lighter than summer. I’ll include official or reputable sources for each.

---

## 1. See Cherry Blossoms Around the City

Spring is prime sakura season (typically early April, but can range late March–mid April depending on weather).

**Top spots:**
- **Queen Elizabeth Park** – Densely planted cherry trees with city and mountain views.  
  - Info: Vancouver Board of Parks and Recreation – Queen Elizabeth Park  
    https://vancouver.ca/parks-recreation-culture/queen-elizabeth-park.aspx
- **Stanley Park (Stanley Park Drive & Rose Garden area)** – Blossoms plus seawall views.  
  - Park info: https://vancouver.ca/parks-recreation-culture/stanley-park.aspx
- **Downtown & West End streets** – Notably around Burrard Station, Nicola St, and Beach Ave.
- **Vancouver Cherry Blossom Festival** – Usually early–late April; includes guided walks, bike rides, and cultural events.  
  - Official site: https://www.vcbf.ca/

---

## 2. Explore Stanley Park & the Seawall

Spring is ideal: fewer tourists than summer, but usually mild and bright.

**What to do:**
- Walk or bike the **Seawall** (10 km loop around the park).
- Visit **Totem Poles at Brockton Point**.
- Detour into the forest trails (less muddy than winter, fresher than summer).

**Bike rentals:** along Denman St near the park entrance (e.g., Spokes, Yes Cycle).

**Sources:**
- City of Vancouver – Stanley Park:  
  https://vancouver.ca/parks-recreation-culture/stanley-park.aspx
- Vancouver Seawall overview (Tourism Vancouver / Destination Vancouver):  
  https://www.destinationvancouver.com/vancouver/neighbourhoods/stanley-park-seawall/

---

## 3. Visit Queen Elizabeth Park & Bloedel Conservatory

At 152 m above sea level, this is Vancouver’s highest point and a spring flower hotspot.

**Highlights:**
- **Seasonal gardens** – Rhododendrons, cherry blossoms, and manicured beds.
- **Bloedel Conservatory** – Tropical dome with exotic plants and free-flying birds; great if it’s raining.  
  - Info & tickets: https://vancouver.ca/parks-recreation-culture/bloedel-conservatory.aspx

**Park info:**  
https://vancouver.ca/parks-recreation-culture/queen-elizabeth-park.aspx

---

## 4. Wander VanDusen Botanical Garden

Spring brings magnolias, rhododendrons, camellias, and early roses.

**Why go in spring:**
- Peak bloom for many collections.
- Less crowded than during the December Festival of Lights.

**Details & tickets:**  
https://vandusengarden.org/

---

## 5. Stroll the University of British Columbia (UBC) Area

The UBC peninsula is especially pretty in spring.

**Key spots:**
- **UBC Botanical Garden** – Forested garden with magnolias, rhodos, and a canopy walk (Greenheart TreeWalk, seasonal).  
  https://botanicalgarden.ubc.ca/
- **Nitobe Memorial Garden** – Traditional Japanese garden that’s stunning during cherry blossom season.  
  https://botanicalgarden.ubc.ca/visit/nitobe-memorial-garden/
- **Pacific Spirit Regional Park** – Lush forest trails; great for a quiet spring hike.  
  Metro Vancouver info: https://metrovancouver.org/services/regional-parks/pacific-spirit-regional-park

---

## 6. Enjoy Granville Island Public Market

Spring is shoulder season: lively but not packed like July–August.

**What to do:**
- Browse the **Public Market** for local produce, seafood, and snacks.
- Check out artisan studios and galleries.
- Take a **False Creek ferry** for scenic short rides.

**Official info:**  
https://granvilleisland.com/

---

## 7. Spring Hikes & Nature Walks

Trails start drying out, and snow recedes at lower elevations.

**Good spring options (check conditions first):**
- **Lynn Canyon Park** (North Vancouver) – Suspension bridge, waterfalls, forest trails.  
  https://www.lynncanyon.ca/
- **Capilano River Regional Park** – Views of Cleveland Dam and Capilano River.  
  https://metrovancouver.org/services/regional-parks/capilano-river-regional-park
- **Burnaby Mountain / SFU area** – Forest trails and views over Burrard Inlet.  
  https://www.burnaby.ca/explore-outdoors/parks/burnaby-mountain-conservation-area

For trail conditions and difficulty, use:
- Vancouver Trails: https://www.vancouvertrails.com/

---

## 8. Visit Capilano Suspension Bridge Park (or Lynn Canyon as a Free Alternative)

Spring means fewer crowds and lush greenery.

**Capilano Suspension Bridge Park:**
- Suspension bridge, cliffwalk, treetop walkways.
- Often has seasonal programming.  
  Official site: https://www.capbridge.com/

**Lynn Canyon Suspension Bridge:**
- Free, more low-key, with forest trails and swimming holes (too cold for swimming in spring, but scenic).  
  https://www.lynncanyon.ca/

---

## 9. Bike Around the City

Spring temperatures are ideal for cycling.

**Popular routes:**
- **Seawall** (Coal Harbour → Stanley Park → English Bay → False Creek).
- **Arbutus Greenway** – A multi-use path through several neighbourhoods.  
  City info: https://vancouver.ca/streets-transportation/arbutus-greenway.aspx

**Bike route maps:**  
City of Vancouver Cycling Routes: https://vancouver.ca/streets-transportation/cycling-routes-maps-and-trip-planner.aspx

---

## 10. Explore Neighbourhoods in Bloom

Spring is great for just walking around:

- **Kitsilano** – Beach, cafes, and leafy streets with blossoms.  
  Neighbourhood overview: https://www.destinationvancouver.com/vancouver/neighbourhoods/kitsilano/
- **Mount Pleasant / Main Street** – Street art, independent shops, breweries, and lots of flowering trees.  
- **West End** – Close to English Bay and Stanley Park; many blossom-lined streets.

---

## 11. Whale Watching (Late Spring)

From April onward, whale-watching tours ramp up, with chances to see orcas, humpbacks, and other marine life.

**Departure points:** Downtown Vancouver (Coal Harbour or Granville Island) and nearby Steveston.

**Operators & info:**
- Prince of Whales: https://princeofwhales.com/
- Wild Whales Vancouver: https://wildwhalesvancouver.com/

Check each operator’s “When to Go” or FAQ pages for seasonal details.

---

## 12. Visit Museums & Indoor Attractions on Rainy Days

Spring can still be wet, so have some indoor options:

- **Museum of Anthropology at UBC** (currently undergoing seismic upgrades; check status before going).  
  https://moa.ubc.ca/
- **Vancouver Art Gallery** – Rotating exhibitions; nice café and patio.  
  https://www.vanartgallery.bc.ca/
- **Science World** – Interactive exhibits; good if you enjoy hands-on science or are traveling with kids.  
  https://www.scienceworld.ca/

---

## 13. Attend Spring Events & Festivals

Exact dates vary by year, but typical spring events include:

- **Vancouver Cherry Blossom Festival** (April)  
  https://www.vcbf.ca/
- **Vancouver International Wine Festival** (often late winter/early spring)  
  https://vanwinefest.ca/
- **BMO Vancouver Marathon** (early May) – Even if you don’t run, the city has a festive atmosphere.  
  https://bmovanmarathon.ca/

Check Destination Vancouver’s events calendar for your specific dates:  
https://www.destinationvancouver.com/events/

---

If you tell me your exact travel dates, interests (e.g., hiking vs food vs art), and whether you’ll have a car, I can narrow this down into a 2–3 day spring itinerary tailored to you.

Prompt: What are the best things to do in Vancouver in Spring?
Full_Prompt: What are the best things to do in Vancouver in Spring? Give me sources for your answer where applicable.
Answer:
Here are some of the best things to do in Vancouver in spring (March–May), when flowers are blooming, days are longer, and crowds are lighter than summer. I’ll include official or reputable sources you can check for details and current conditions.

---

## 1. See Cherry Blossoms & Spring Flowers

**Vancouver Cherry Blossom Festival (early April, dates vary)**  
- Neighborhoods like **Kitsilano, West End, Yaletown, and East Van** are lined with cherry trees.  
- Signature spots:
  - **Queen Elizabeth Park** – great views + blossoms  
  - **Stanley Park’s** Chilco Street and Lagoon Drive  
  - **UBC campus** (esp. near Lower Mall & Regent College)  

**Sources**  
- Official festival site with maps & events:  
  https://vcbf.ca  
- City of Vancouver cherry tree map:  
  https://vancouver.ca/parks-recreation-culture/cherry-blossom-trees.aspx  

**VanDusen Botanical Garden & Queen Elizabeth Park**  
- VanDusen has magnolias, rhododendrons, and cherry blossoms in spring.  
- Queen Elizabeth Park has manicured gardens and one of the best city views.

**Sources**  
- VanDusen: https://vandusengarden.org  
- Queen Elizabeth Park: https://vancouver.ca/parks-recreation-culture/queen-elizabeth-park.aspx  

---

## 2. Explore Stanley Park & the Seawall

Spring is ideal: fewer tourists than summer, and the forest is lush.

**Top things to do:**
- Walk or bike the **Seawall** (10 km loop around the park).  
- Visit **Totem Poles at Brockton Point**.  
- Check out **Beaver Lake** and **Lost Lagoon** for birdlife.  
- Stop at **Prospect Point** for views of Lions Gate Bridge and the North Shore.

**Bike rentals** are easy to find on Denman Street near the park entrance.

**Sources**  
- Stanley Park overview: https://vancouver.ca/parks-recreation-culture/stanley-park.aspx  
- Seawall info: https://vancouver.ca/parks-recreation-culture/seawall.aspx  

---

## 3. Visit Granville Island

A great all-weather option, especially in shoulder-season spring.

**Highlights:**
- **Public Market** – local produce, seafood, bakeries, and food stalls.  
- Art studios, galleries, and artisan shops.  
- **Granville Island Brewing** and other tasting spots.  
- Views back toward downtown and False Creek.

**Source**  
- Official site: https://granvilleisland.com  

---

## 4. Walk the Seawall from Olympic Village to English Bay

Beyond Stanley Park, the **False Creek and English Bay** sections are perfect in spring.

**Ideas:**
- Start at **Olympic Village** (cafés, craft breweries), walk or bike past **Science World**, **Yaletown**, **Sunset Beach**, and end at **English Bay**.  
- Time it for sunset at English Bay if the weather is clear.

**Source**  
- Seawall map (PDF): https://vancouver.ca/files/cov/Seawall-map.pdf  

---

## 5. Capilano Suspension Bridge & Lynn Canyon

Spring is a good time before peak crowds; forests are bright green with new growth.

**Capilano Suspension Bridge Park (North Vancouver)**  
- Main suspension bridge, **Cliffwalk**, and **Treetops Adventure**.  
- More touristy and pricey, but very photogenic.

**Source**  
- https://www.capbridge.com  

**Lynn Canyon Park (North Vancouver)**  
- Free suspension bridge, forest trails, and waterfalls.  
- Less developed than Capilano; can be muddy in spring, so bring good shoes.

**Source**  
- District info: https://www.lynncanyon.ca  

---

## 6. Hike Easy Spring Trails

Snow can linger at higher elevations into May, but many low- to mid-elevation hikes are great in spring.

**Good spring-friendly options (check conditions):**
- **Quarry Rock / Baden-Powell (Deep Cove)** – classic viewpoint over Indian Arm.  
- **Lighthouse Park (West Vancouver)** – old-growth forest and ocean viewpoints.  
- **Pacific Spirit Regional Park (near UBC)** – flat forest trails, good even in light rain.

**Sources**  
- Metro Vancouver parks (Pacific Spirit): https://metrovancouver.org/services/regional-parks/pacific-spirit-regional-park  
- Lighthouse Park: https://westvancouver.ca/parks-recreation/parks-trails/parks/lighthouse-park  
- Trail reports & conditions: https://www.vancouvertrails.com  

---

## 7. Visit UBC: Museum of Anthropology Area & Beaches

Even with ongoing renovations/changes at the Museum of Anthropology (MOA), the UBC area is excellent in spring.

**Things to do:**
- **MOA** – Indigenous art and artifacts; check current status/hours as it has been undergoing seismic upgrades.  
- **Nitobe Memorial Garden** – tranquil Japanese garden, beautiful in cherry blossom season.  
- **UBC Botanical Garden** – forested garden with spring blooms.  
- **Wreck Beach** – long staircase down to a wild-feeling beach; best on a clear day.

**Sources**  
- MOA: https://moa.ubc.ca  
- Nitobe & Botanical Garden: https://botanicalgarden.ubc.ca  

---

## 8. Enjoy Spring at the Beaches

Even if it’s not swimming weather, Vancouver’s beaches are great for walks and sunsets.

**Best spring beaches:**
- **English Bay Beach** – close to downtown; cafés and restaurants nearby.  
- **Sunset Beach** – good for evening walks.  
- **Kitsilano Beach (Kits Beach)** – views of downtown and the North Shore mountains.  
- **Jericho & Locarno** – quieter, more local feel.

**Source**  
- Vancouver beaches overview: https://vancouver.ca/parks-recreation-culture/beaches.aspx  

---

## 9. Check Out Spring Festivals & Events

Timing varies year to year, but typical spring events include:

- **Vancouver Cherry Blossom Festival** (April) – walks, bike rides, cultural events.  
  - https://vcbf.ca  
- **Vancouver International Wine Festival** (often late Feb–early March):  
  - https://vanwinefest.ca  
- **Vancouver Sun Run** (April) – one of Canada’s largest 10K runs; fun city atmosphere even if you don’t run.  
  - https://vancouversunrun.com  

Check Tourism Vancouver’s event listings for your specific dates:  
https://www.destinationvancouver.com/events/

---

## 10. Food & Neighborhood Wandering

Spring is a good time to explore neighborhoods before peak summer crowds.

**Gastown**  
- Historic cobblestone streets, restaurants, and bars.  
- Good for evening drinks and dining.

**Chinatown**  
- One of North America’s oldest Chinatowns.  
- Visit the **Dr. Sun Yat-Sen Classical Chinese Garden** (check hours).  
  - https://vancouverchinesegarden.com  

**Commercial Drive (“The Drive”)**  
- Cafés, Italian and global eateries, independent shops; lively but less touristy.

**Mount Pleasant / Main Street**  
- Breweries, coffee shops, street art, and boutiques.

**Food & drink resources**  
- Destination Vancouver dining:  
  https://www.destinationvancouver.com/restaurants/  
- Vancouver brewery map (example):  
  https://bcaletrail.ca/city/vancouver/

---

## 11. Day Trips from Vancouver in Spring

If you have extra time:

**1. Whistler**  
- Spring skiing (often into April), plus village walks and early-season hiking/biking lower down.  
- Source: https://www.whistler.com  

**2. Steveston Village (Richmond)**  
- Historic fishing village, waterfront walks, and seafood.  
- Source: https://www.visitrichmondbc.com/places-to-go/steveston/  

**3. Bowen Island**  
- Short ferry from Horseshoe Bay; good for easy hikes and a quiet village vibe.  
- Info: https://tourismbowenisland.com  

---

If you share your exact travel dates and interests (e.g., more hiking vs. food vs. museums), I can narrow this down into a 2–4 day spring itinerary tailored to you, including likely weather and transit options from San Francisco.

Prompt: What are the best things to do in Vancouver in Spring?

---

## 1. See Cherry Blossoms & Spring Flowers

**Vancouver Cherry Blossom Festival (early April, dates vary)**  
- Neighborhoods like **Kitsilano, West End, Yaletown, and East Van** are lined with cherry trees.  
- Signature spots:
  - **Queen Elizabeth Park** – great views + blossoms  
  - **Stanley Park’s** Chilco Street and Lagoon Drive  
  - **UBC campus** (esp. near Lower Mall & Regent College)  

**Sources**

  https://vcbf.ca  
- City of Vancouver cherry tree map:  
  https://vancouver.ca/parks-recreation-culture/cherry-blossom-trees.aspx  

**VanDusen Botanical Garden & Queen Elizabeth Park**  
- VanDusen has magnolias, rhododendrons, and cherry blossoms in spring.  
- Queen Elizabeth Park has manicured gardens and one of the best city views.

**Sources**  
- VanDusen: https://vandusengarden.org  
- Queen Elizabeth Park: https://vancouver.ca/parks-recreation-culture/queen-elizabeth-park.aspx  

---

## 2. Explore Stanley Park & the Seawall

Spring is ideal: fewer tourists than summer, and the forest is lush.

**Top things to do:**
- Walk or bike the **Seawall** (10 km loop around the park).  
- Visit **Totem Poles at Brockton Point**.  
- Check out **Beaver Lake** and **Lost Lagoon** for birdlife.  
- Stop at **Prospect Point** for views of Lions Gate Bridge and the North Shore.

**Bike rentals** are easy to find on Denman Street near the park entrance.

**Sources**  
- Stanley Park overview: https://vancouver.ca/parks-recreation-culture/stanley-park.aspx  
- Seawall info: https://vancouver.ca/parks-recreation-culture/seawall.aspx  

---

## 3. Visit Granville Island

A great all-weather option, especially in shoulder-season spring.

**Highlights:**
- **Public Market** – local produce, seafood, bakeries, and food stalls.  
- Art studios, galleries, and artisan shops.  
- **Granville Island Brewing** and other tasting spots.  
- Views back toward downtown and False Creek.

**Source**  
- Official site: https://granvilleisland.com  

---

## 4. Walk the Seawall from Olympic Village to English Bay

Beyond Stanley Park, the **False Creek and English Bay** sections are perfect in spring.

**Ideas:**
- Start at **Olympic Village** (cafés, craft breweries), walk or bike past **Science World**, **Yaletown**, **Sunset Beach**, and end at **English Bay**.  
- Time it for sunset at English Bay if the weather is clear.

---

## 5. Capilano Suspension Bridge & Lynn Canyon

Spring is a good time before peak crowds; forests are bright green with new growth.

**Capilano Suspension Bridge Park (North Vancouver)**  
- Main suspension bridge, **Cliffwalk**, and **Treetops Adventure**.  
- More touristy and pricey, but very photogenic.

**Source**  
- https://www.capbridge.com  

**Lynn Canyon Park (North Vancouver)**  
- Free suspension bridge, forest trails, and waterfalls.  
- Less developed than Capilano; can be muddy in spring, so bring good shoes.

**Source**  
- District info: https://www.lynncanyon.ca  

---

## 6. Hike Easy Spring Trails

Snow can linger at higher elevations into May, but many low- to mid-elevation hikes are great in spring.

**Good spring-friendly options (check conditions):**
- **Quarry Rock / Baden-Powell (Deep Cove)** – classic viewpoint over Indian Arm.  
- **Lighthouse Park (West Vancouver)** – old-growth forest and ocean viewpoints.

- Queen Elizabeth Park: https://vancouver.ca/parks-recreation-culture/queen-elizabeth-park.aspx

Spring is ideal: fewer tourists than summer, and the forest is lush.

- Walk or bike the **Seawall** (10 km loop around the park).

- Check out **Beaver Lake** and **Lost Lagoon** for birdlife.  
- Stop at **Prospect Point** for views of Lions Gate Bridge and the North Shore.

- Seawall info: https://vancouver.ca/parks-recreation-culture/seawall.aspx

## 3. Visit Granville Island

A great all-weather option, especially in shoulder-season spring.

**Highlights:**
- **Public Market** – local produce, seafood, bakeries, and food stalls.  
- Art studios, galleries, and artisan shops.  
- **Granville Island Brewing** and other tasting spots.  
- Views back toward downtown and False Creek.

**Source**  
- Official site: https://granvilleisland.com  

---

## 4. Walk the Seawall from Olympic Village to English Bay

Beyond Stanley Park, the **False Creek and English Bay** sections are perfect in spring.

**Ideas:**
- Start at **Olympic Village** (cafés, craft breweries), walk or bike past **Science World**, **Yaletown**, **Sunset Beach**, and end at **English Bay**.  
- Time it for sunset at English Bay if the weather is clear.

## 5. Capilano Suspension Bridge & Lynn Canyon

Spring is a good time before peak crowds; forests are bright green with new growth.

Snow can linger at higher elevations into May, but many low- to mid-elevation hikes are great in spring.

Prompt: What are the best things to do in Vancouver in Spring?
Full_Prompt: What are the best things to do in Vancouver in Spring? Give me sources for your answer where applicable.
Answer:
Here are some of the best things to do in Vancouver in spring (March–May), when flowers are blooming, days are longer, and crowds are lighter than summer. I’ll include official or reputable sources you can check for details and current conditions.

---

## 1. See Cherry Blossoms & Spring Flowers

**Vancouver Cherry Blossom Festival (early April, dates vary)**  
- Neighborhoods like **Kitsilano, West End, Yaletown, and East Van** are lined with cherry trees.  
- Signature spots:
  - **Queen Elizabeth Park** – great views + blossoms  
  - **Stanley Park’s** Chilco Street and Lagoon Drive  
  - **UBC campus** (esp. near Lower Mall & Regent College)  

**Sources**  
- Official festival site with maps & events:  
  https://vcbf.ca  
- City of Vancouver cherry tree map:  
  https://vancouver.ca/parks-recreation-culture/cherry-blossom-trees.aspx  

**VanDusen Botanical Garden & Queen Elizabeth Park**  
- VanDusen has magnolias, rhododendrons, and cherry blossoms in spring.  
- Queen Elizabeth Park has manicured gardens and one of the best city views.

**Sources**  
- VanDusen: https://vandusengarden.org  
- Queen Elizabeth Park: https://vancouver.ca/parks-recreation-culture/queen-elizabeth-park.aspx  

---

## 2. Explore Stanley Park & the Seawall

Spring is ideal: fewer tourists than summer, and the forest is lush.

**Top things to do:**
- Walk or bike the **Seawall** (10 km loop around the park).  
- Visit **Totem Poles at Brockton Point**.  
- Check out **Beaver Lake** and **Lost Lagoon** for birdlife.  
- Stop at **Prospect Point** for views of Lions Gate Bridge and the North Shore.

**Bike rentals** are easy to find on Denman Street near the park entrance.

**Sources**  
- Stanley Park overview: https://vancouver.ca/parks-recreation-culture/stanley-park.aspx  
- Seawall info: https://vancouver.ca/parks-recreation-culture/seawall.aspx  

---

## 3. Visit Granville Island

A great all-weather option, especially in shoulder-season spring.

**Highlights:**
- **Public Market** – local produce, seafood, bakeries, and food stalls.  
- Art studios, galleries, and artisan shops.  
- **Granville Island Brewing** and other tasting spots.  
- Views back toward downtown and False Creek.

**Source**  
- Official site: https://granvilleisland.com  

---

## 4. Walk the Seawall from Olympic Village to English Bay

Beyond Stanley Park, the **False Creek and English Bay** sections are perfect in spring.

**Ideas:**
- Start at **Olympic Village** (cafés, craft breweries), walk or bike past **Science World**, **Yaletown**, **Sunset Beach**, and end at **English Bay**.  
- Time it for sunset at English Bay if the weather is clear.

**Source**  
- Seawall map (PDF): https://vancouver.ca/files/cov/Seawall-map.pdf  

---

## 5. Capilano Suspension Bridge & Lynn Canyon

Spring is a good time before peak crowds; forests are bright green with new growth.

**Capilano Suspension Bridge Park (North Vancouver)**  
- Main suspension bridge, **Cliffwalk**, and **Treetops Adventure**.  
- More touristy and pricey, but very photogenic.

**Source**  
- https://www.capbridge.com  

**Lynn Canyon Park (North Vancouver)**  
- Free suspension bridge, forest trails, and waterfalls.  
- Less developed than Capilano; can be muddy in spring, so bring good shoes.

**Source**  
- District info: https://www.lynncanyon.ca  

---

## 6. Hike Easy Spring Trails

Snow can linger at higher elevations into May, but many low- to mid-elevation hikes are great in spring.

**Good spring-friendly options (check conditions):**
- **Quarry Rock / Baden-Powell (Deep Cove)** – classic viewpoint over Indian Arm.  
- **Lighthouse Park (West Vancouver)** – old-growth forest and ocean viewpoints.  
- **Pacific Spirit Regional Park (near UBC)** – flat forest trails, good even in light rain.

**Sources**  
- Metro Vancouver parks (Pacific Spirit): https://metrovancouver.org/services/regional-parks/pacific-spirit-regional-park  
- Lighthouse Park: https://westvancouver.ca/parks-recreation/parks-trails/parks/lighthouse-park  
- Trail reports & conditions: https://www.vancouvertrails.com  

---

## 7. Visit UBC: Museum of Anthropology Area & Beaches

Even with ongoing renovations/changes at the Museum of Anthropology (MOA), the UBC area is excellent in spring.

**Things to do:**
- **MOA** – Indigenous art and artifacts; check current status/hours as it has been undergoing seismic upgrades.  
- **Nitobe Memorial Garden** – tranquil Japanese garden, beautiful in cherry blossom season.  
- **UBC Botanical Garden** – forested garden with spring blooms.  
- **Wreck Beach** – long staircase down to a wild-feeling beach; best on a clear day.

**Sources**  
- MOA: https://moa.ubc.ca  
- Nitobe & Botanical Garden: https://botanicalgarden.ubc.ca  

---

## 8. Enjoy Spring at the Beaches

Even if it’s not swimming weather, Vancouver’s beaches are great for walks and sunsets.

**Best spring beaches:**
- **English Bay Beach** – close to downtown; cafés and restaurants nearby.  
- **Sunset Beach** – good for evening walks.  
- **Kitsilano Beach (Kits Beach)** – views of downtown and the North Shore mountains.  
- **Jericho & Locarno** – quieter, more local feel.

**Source**  
- Vancouver beaches overview: https://vancouver.ca/parks-recreation-culture/beaches.aspx  

---

## 9. Check Out Spring Festivals & Events

- Seawall info: https://vancouver.ca/parks-recreation-culture/seawall.aspx

## 3. Visit Granville Island

A great all-weather option, especially in shoulder-season spring.

**Highlights:**
- **Public Market** – local produce, seafood, bakeries, and food stalls.  
- Art studios, galleries, and artisan shops.  
- **Granville Island Brewing** and other tasting spots.  
- Views back toward downtown and False Creek.

**Source**  
- Official site: https://granvilleisland.com  

---

## 4. Walk the Seawall from Olympic Village to English Bay

Beyond Stanley Park, the **False Creek and English Bay** sections are perfect in spring.

**Ideas:**
- Start at **Olympic Village** (cafés, craft breweries), walk or bike past **Science World**, **Yaletown**, **Sunset Beach**, and end at **English Bay**.  
- Time it for sunset at English Bay if the weather is clear.

**Source**  
- Seawall map (PDF): https://vancouver.ca/files/cov/Seawall-map.pdf  

---

## 5. Capilano Suspension Bridge & Lynn Canyon

Spring is a good time before peak crowds; forests are bright green with new growth.

**Capilano Suspension Bridge Park (North Vancouver)**  
- Main suspension bridge, **Cliffwalk**, and **Treetops Adventure**.  
- More touristy and pricey, but very photogenic.

**Source**  
- https://www.capbridge.com  

**Lynn Canyon Park (North Vancouver)**  
- Free suspension bridge, forest trails, and waterfalls.  
- Less developed than Capilano; can be muddy in spring, so bring good shoes.

**Source**  
- District info: https://www.lynncanyon.ca  

---

## 6. Hike Easy Spring Trails

Snow can linger at higher elevations into May, but many low- to mid-elevation hikes are great in spring.

**Good spring-friendly options (check conditions):**
- **Quarry Rock / Baden-Powell (Deep Cove)** – classic viewpoint over Indian Arm.  
- **Lighthouse Park (West Vancouver)** – old-growth forest and ocean viewpoints.  
- **Pacific Spirit Regional Park (near UBC)** – flat forest trails, good even in light rain.

## 7. Visit UBC: Museum of Anthropology Area & Beaches

- **MOA** – Indigenous art and artifacts; check current status/hours as it has been undergoing seismic upgrades.  
- **Nitobe Memorial Garden** – tranquil Japanese garden, beautiful in cherry blossom season.  
- **UBC Botanical Garden** – forested garden with spring blooms.  
- **Wreck Beach** – long staircase down to a wild-feeling beach; best on a clear day.

- **Jericho & Locarno** – quieter, more local feel.

- Spring skiing (often into April), plus village walks and early-season hiking/biking lower down.

**2. Steveston Village (Richmond)**  
- Historic fishing village, waterfront walks, and seafood.

Prompt: What are the best things to do in Vancouver in Spring?
Full_Prompt: What are the best things to do in Vancouver in Spring? Give me sources for your answer where applicable.
Answer:
Here are some of the best things to do in Vancouver in spring (March–May), when flowers are blooming, days are longer, and crowds are lighter than summer. I’ll include official or reputable sources you can check for details and current conditions.

---

## 1. See Cherry Blossoms & Spring Flowers

**Vancouver Cherry Blossom Festival (early April, dates vary)**  
- Neighborhoods like **Kitsilano, West End, Yaletown, and East Van** are lined with cherry trees.  
- Signature spots:
  - **Queen Elizabeth Park** – great views + blossoms  
  - **Stanley Park’s** Chilco Street and Lagoon Drive  
  - **UBC campus** (esp. near Lower Mall & Regent College)  

**Sources**  
- Official festival site with maps & events:  
  https://vcbf.ca  
- City of Vancouver cherry tree map:  
  https://vancouver.ca/parks-recreation-culture/cherry-blossom-trees.aspx  

**VanDusen Botanical Garden & Queen Elizabeth Park**  
- VanDusen has magnolias, rhododendrons, and cherry blossoms in spring.  
- Queen Elizabeth Park has manicured gardens and one of the best city views.

**Sources**  
- VanDusen: https://vandusengarden.org  
- Queen Elizabeth Park: https://vancouver.ca/parks-recreation-culture/queen-elizabeth-park.aspx  

---

## 2. Explore Stanley Park & the Seawall

Spring is ideal: fewer tourists than summer, and the forest is lush.

**Top things to do:**
- Walk or bike the **Seawall** (10 km loop around the park).  
- Visit **Totem Poles at Brockton Point**.  
- Check out **Beaver Lake** and **Lost Lagoon** for birdlife.  
- Stop at **Prospect Point** for views of Lions Gate Bridge and the North Shore.

**Bike rentals** are easy to find on Denman Street near the park entrance.

**Sources**  
- Stanley Park overview: https://vancouver.ca/parks-recreation-culture/stanley-park.aspx  
- Seawall info: https://vancouver.ca/parks-recreation-culture/seawall.aspx  

---

## 3. Visit Granville Island

A great all-weather option, especially in shoulder-season spring.

**Highlights:**
- **Public Market** – local produce, seafood, bakeries, and food stalls.  
- Art studios, galleries, and artisan shops.  
- **Granville Island Brewing** and other tasting spots.  
- Views back toward downtown and False Creek.

**Source**  
- Official site: https://granvilleisland.com  

---

## 4. Walk the Seawall from Olympic Village to English Bay

Beyond Stanley Park, the **False Creek and English Bay** sections are perfect in spring.

**Ideas:**
- Start at **Olympic Village** (cafés, craft breweries), walk or bike past **Science World**, **Yaletown**, **Sunset Beach**, and end at **English Bay**.  
- Time it for sunset at English Bay if the weather is clear.

**Source**  
- Seawall map (PDF): https://vancouver.ca/files/cov/Seawall-map.pdf  

---

## 5. Capilano Suspension Bridge & Lynn Canyon

Spring is a good time before peak crowds; forests are bright green with new growth.

**Capilano Suspension Bridge Park (North Vancouver)**  
- Main suspension bridge, **Cliffwalk**, and **Treetops Adventure**.  
- More touristy and pricey, but very photogenic.

**Source**  
- https://www.capbridge.com  

**Lynn Canyon Park (North Vancouver)**  
- Free suspension bridge, forest trails, and waterfalls.  
- Less developed than Capilano; can be muddy in spring, so bring good shoes.

**Source**  
- District info: https://www.lynncanyon.ca  

---

## 6. Hike Easy Spring Trails

Snow can linger at higher elevations into May, but many low- to mid-elevation hikes are great in spring.

**Good spring-friendly options (check conditions):**
- **Quarry Rock / Baden-Powell (Deep Cove)** – classic viewpoint over Indian Arm.  
- **Lighthouse Park (West Vancouver)** – old-growth forest and ocean viewpoints.  
- **Pacific Spirit Regional Park (near UBC)** – flat forest trails, good even in light rain.

**Sources**  
- Metro Vancouver parks (Pacific Spirit): https://metrovancouver.org/services/regional-parks/pacific-spirit-regional-park  
- Lighthouse Park: https://westvancouver.ca/parks-recreation/parks-trails/parks/lighthouse-park  
- Trail reports & conditions: https://www.vancouvertrails.com  

---

## 7. Visit UBC: Museum of Anthropology Area & Beaches

Even with ongoing renovations/changes at the Museum of Anthropology (MOA), the UBC area is excellent in spring.

**Things to do:**
- **MOA** – Indigenous art and artifacts; check current status/hours as it has been undergoing seismic upgrades.  
- **Nitobe Memorial Garden** – tranquil Japanese garden, beautiful in cherry blossom season.  
- **UBC Botanical Garden** – forested garden with spring blooms.  
- **Wreck Beach** – long staircase down to a wild-feeling beach; best on a clear day.

**Sources**  
- MOA: https://moa.ubc.ca  
- Nitobe & Botanical Garden: https://botanicalgarden.ubc.ca  

---

## 8. Enjoy Spring at the Beaches

Even if it’s not swimming weather, Vancouver’s beaches are great for walks and sunsets.

**Best spring beaches:**
- **English Bay Beach** – close to downtown; cafés and restaurants nearby.  
- **Sunset Beach** – good for evening walks.  
- **Kitsilano Beach (Kits Beach)** – views of downtown and the North Shore mountains.  
- **Jericho & Locarno** – quieter, more local feel.

**Source**  
- Vancouver beaches overview: https://vancouver.ca/parks-recreation-culture/beaches.aspx  

---

## 9. Check Out Spring Festivals & Events

Timing varies year to year, but typical spring events include:

- **Vancouver Cherry Blossom Festival** (April) – walks, bike rides, cultural events.  
  - https://vcbf.ca  
- **Vancouver International Wine Festival** (often late Feb–early March):

  - **Queen Elizabeth Park** – great views + blossoms

- VanDusen has magnolias, rhododendrons, and cherry blossoms in spring.

- Queen Elizabeth Park: https://vancouver.ca/parks-recreation-culture/queen-elizabeth-park.aspx  

---

## 2. Explore Stanley Park & the Seawall

Spring is ideal: fewer tourists than summer, and the forest is lush.

**Top things to do:**
- Walk or bike the **Seawall** (10 km loop around the park).  
- Visit **Totem Poles at Brockton Point**.  
- Check out **Beaver Lake** and **Lost Lagoon** for birdlife.  
- Stop at **Prospect Point** for views of Lions Gate Bridge and the North Shore.

**Bike rentals** are easy to find on Denman Street near the park entrance.

**Sources**  
- Stanley Park overview: https://vancouver.ca/parks-recreation-culture/stanley-park.aspx  
- Seawall info: https://vancouver.ca/parks-recreation-culture/seawall.aspx  

---

## 3. Visit Granville Island

A great all-weather option, especially in shoulder-season spring.

**Highlights:**
- **Public Market** – local produce, seafood, bakeries, and food stalls.  
- Art studios, galleries, and artisan shops.  
- **Granville Island Brewing** and other tasting spots.  
- Views back toward downtown and False Creek.

**Source**  
- Official site: https://granvilleisland.com  

---

## 4. Walk the Seawall from Olympic Village to English Bay

Beyond Stanley Park, the **False Creek and English Bay** sections are perfect in spring.

**Ideas:**
- Start at **Olympic Village** (cafés, craft breweries), walk or bike past **Science World**, **Yaletown**, **Sunset Beach**, and end at **English Bay**.

## 5. Capilano Suspension Bridge & Lynn Canyon

Spring is a good time before peak crowds; forests are bright green with new growth.

- Main suspension bridge, **Cliffwalk**, and **Treetops Adventure**.  
- More touristy and pricey, but very photogenic.

- https://www.capbridge.com

- District info: https://www.lynncanyon.ca

Snow can linger at higher elevations into May, but many low- to mid-elevation hikes are great in spring.

**Timing:** Typically early April, but varies by year.

**What to do:**
- Join events from the **Vancouver Cherry Blossom Festival** (concerts, guided walks, bike rides, “The Big Picnic” in David Lam Park some years).
- Self-guided blossom viewing in:
  - **Queen Elizabeth Park**
  - **Stanley Park**
  - **UBC campus**
  - Neighborhoods like **Kitsilano**, **Yaletown**, and **West End**

**Info & blossom maps:**

  https://www.vcbf.ca/blooming-now/neighbourhood-maps

---

## 3. Queen Elizabeth Park & Bloedel Conservatory

**Why spring?** Gardens are at their best; great city and mountain views on clear days.

**Highlights:**
- Quarry Garden and rose garden (roses peak later, but spring flowers are lovely).
- **Bloedel Conservatory** – tropical plants and free-flying birds in a domed greenhouse (nice backup if it’s raining).

**Info:**
- Queen Elizabeth Park:  
  https://vancouver.ca/parks-recreation-culture/queen-elizabeth-park.aspx  
- Bloedel Conservatory:  
  https://vancouver.ca/parks-recreation-culture/bloedel-conservatory.aspx

---

**What to do:**

- Seasonal events and plant sales in spring.

**Info:**
- VanDusen Botanical Garden:  
  https://vandusengarden.ca/

---

## 5. Granville Island Public Market

**Good in any weather; especially nice in mild spring temps.**

**What to do:**
- Browse the **Public Market** for local produce, baked goods, and lunch.
- Visit artisan shops and galleries in the former industrial buildings.
- Take a **False Creek ferry** ride for views of downtown and the mountains.

  https://granvilleisland.com/

  https://www.granvilleislandferries.bc.ca/

  https://theaquabus.com/

---

## 6. Seawall & City Cycling

**Why spring?** Comfortable temps and longer daylight; less crowded than summer.

**Ideas:**

Prompt: What are the best things to do in Vancouver in Spring?
Full_Prompt: What are the best things to do in Vancouver in Spring? Give me sources for your answer where applicable.
Answer:
Here are some of the best things to do in Vancouver in spring (roughly March–May), with links so you can check details and current conditions from Seattle before you go.

---

## 1. Explore Stanley Park in Bloom

**Why spring?** Cherry blossoms, fresh greenery, and fewer summer crowds.

**Top activities:**
- Walk or bike the **Seawall** (10 km loop around the park).
- Visit **Beaver Lake** and **Lost Lagoon** for birds and spring foliage.
- Check out **Totem Poles** at Brockton Point.
- Stop at **Vancouver Aquarium** (inside the park).

**Info & maps:**
- City of Vancouver – Stanley Park:  
  https://vancouver.ca/parks-recreation-culture/stanley-park.aspx  
- Vancouver Aquarium:  
  https://www.vanaqua.org/

---

## 2. Cherry Blossoms & Vancouver Cherry Blossom Festival

**Timing:** Typically early April, but varies by year.

**What to do:**
- Join events from the **Vancouver Cherry Blossom Festival** (concerts, guided walks, bike rides, “The Big Picnic” in David Lam Park some years).
- Self-guided blossom viewing in:
  - **Queen Elizabeth Park**
  - **Stanley Park**
  - **UBC campus**
  - Neighborhoods like **Kitsilano**, **Yaletown**, and **West End**

**Info & blossom maps:**
- Vancouver Cherry Blossom Festival:  
  https://www.vcbf.ca/  
- Blossom map:  
  https://www.vcbf.ca/blooming-now/neighbourhood-maps

---

## 3. Queen Elizabeth Park & Bloedel Conservatory

**Why spring?** Gardens are at their best; great city and mountain views on clear days.

**Highlights:**
- Quarry Garden and rose garden (roses peak later, but spring flowers are lovely).
- **Bloedel Conservatory** – tropical plants and free-flying birds in a domed greenhouse (nice backup if it’s raining).

**Info:**
- Queen Elizabeth Park:  
  https://vancouver.ca/parks-recreation-culture/queen-elizabeth-park.aspx  
- Bloedel Conservatory:  
  https://vancouver.ca/parks-recreation-culture/bloedel-conservatory.aspx

---

## 4. VanDusen Botanical Garden

**Why spring?** Rhododendrons, magnolias, cherry blossoms, and bulbs (tulips, daffodils) are in bloom.

**What to do:**
- Wander themed gardens (Japanese, Korean, Mediterranean, etc.).
- Seasonal events and plant sales in spring.

**Info:**
- VanDusen Botanical Garden:  
  https://vandusengarden.ca/

---

## 5. Granville Island Public Market

**Good in any weather; especially nice in mild spring temps.**

**What to do:**
- Browse the **Public Market** for local produce, baked goods, and lunch.
- Visit artisan shops and galleries in the former industrial buildings.
- Take a **False Creek ferry** ride for views of downtown and the mountains.

**Info:**
- Granville Island:  
  https://granvilleisland.com/  
- False Creek Ferries:  
  https://www.granvilleislandferries.bc.ca/  
- Aquabus:  
  https://theaquabus.com/

---

## 6. Seawall & City Cycling

**Why spring?** Comfortable temps and longer daylight; less crowded than summer.

**Ideas:**
- Rent bikes near **Denman Street** or **Coal Harbour** and ride:
  - Stanley Park Seawall
  - Around **False Creek** (Science World → Olympic Village → Granville Island)
- Or walk the shorter sections if you prefer.

**Info:**
- Vancouver Seawall overview:  
  https://vancouver.ca/parks-recreation-culture/seawall.aspx

---

## 7. Capilano Suspension Bridge Park or Lynn Canyon

**Why spring?** Lush green rainforest, full rivers and waterfalls from snowmelt.

**Capilano Suspension Bridge Park (paid, more developed):**
- Suspension bridge, treetop walkways, and cliffwalk.
- More touristy but very photogenic.

**Lynn Canyon Park (by donation/parking fees, more natural):**
- Suspension bridge, forest trails, waterfalls.
- Great if you prefer a less commercial feel.

**Info:**
- Capilano Suspension Bridge Park:  
  https://www.capbridge.com/  
- Lynn Canyon Park:  
  https://lynncanyon.ca/

---

## 8. Grouse Mountain – “The Peak of Vancouver”

**Spring specifics:**
- Early spring: still snow sports (skiing, snowshoeing) and winter scenery.
- Late spring: hiking trails start to open; **Grouse Grind** typically opens late spring/early summer depending on conditions.

**What to do:**
- Take the **Skyride** gondola for city and mountain views.
- Visit wildlife refuge (grizzly bears in season), lumberjack shows, and viewpoints.

**Info:**
- Grouse Mountain:  
  https://www.grousemountain.com/

---

## 9. UBC Campus: Museum of Anthropology Area & Beaches

**Note:** The Museum of Anthropology has been undergoing seismic upgrades; check status before you go.

**What to do:**
- Walk the UBC campus and Pacific Spirit Regional Park trails.
- Visit **Wreck Beach** (steep stairs, clothing-optional) or **Spanish Banks/Jericho Beach** for views of downtown and the North Shore mountains.
- If open: **Museum of Anthropology** for Indigenous art and architecture.

**Info:**
- Museum of Anthropology:  
  https://moa.ubc.ca/  
- Pacific Spirit Regional Park:  
  https://bcparks.ca/pacific-spirit-park/  
- Vancouver beaches:  
  https://vancouver.ca/parks-recreation-culture/beaches.aspx

---

## 10. Spring Festivals & Events

**Depending on your dates from Seattle, look for:**

- **Vancouver Cherry Blossom Festival** (April):  
  https://www.vcbf.ca/
- **Vancouver International Wine Festival** (often late Feb–early March):  
  https://vanwinefest.ca/
- **Vancouver Sun Run** (April) – big 10K run/walk:  
  https://vancouversunrun.com/
- **Vancouver International Children’s Festival** (late May/early June):  
  https://www.childrensfestival.ca/

Check dates each year; they shift slightly.

---

## 11. Food & Neighborhood Wandering

**Great spring neighborhoods to explore on foot:**
- **Gastown** – historic streets, restaurants, bars, shops.  
  Info: https://gastown.org/
- **Yaletown** – patios and restaurants, especially nice on mild evenings.  
  Info: https://yaletowninfo.com/
- **Commercial Drive** – cafés, Italian and global food, indie shops.  
- **Kitsilano** – West 4th Ave and Kits Beach area; good on a sunny spring day.

For restaurant ideas:
- Tourism Vancouver food & drink:  
  https://www.destinationvancouver.com/restaurants/

---

## 12. Easy Nature Trips from Vancouver (good for a Seattle weekend)

If you have a car:

- **Sea-to-Sky Highway to Squamish/Whistler**
  - **Shannon Falls** (short walk to a big waterfall).  
    Info: https://bcparks.ca/shannon-falls-park/
  - **Sea to Sky Gondola** (trails and viewpoints at the top).  
    Info: https://www.seatoskygondola.com/
- **Steveston Village (Richmond)** – historic fishing village, waterfront walks, seafood.  
  Info: https://www.visitrichmondbc.com/steveston/

---

## 13. Practical Notes from Seattle

- **Travel time:** ~2.5–3 hours driving from Seattle (plus border wait).  
  Border info: https://www.cbsa-asfc.gc.ca/do-rb/menu-eng.html
- **Weather:** Spring is variable—bring layers and a light rain jacket.  
  Forecast: https://weather.gc.ca/city/pages/bc-74_metric_e.html
- **Transit:** SkyTrain and buses are easy for most city sights.  
  TransLink trip planner: https://www.translink.ca/

---

Prompt: What are the best things to do in Vancouver in Spring?
Full_Prompt: What are the best things to do in Vancouver in Spring? Give me sources for your answer where applicable.
Answer:
Here are some of the best things to do in Vancouver in spring (roughly March–May), with links so you can check details and current conditions from Seattle before you go.

---

## 1. Explore Stanley Park in Bloom

**Why spring?** Cherry blossoms, fresh greenery, and fewer summer crowds.

**Top activities:**
- Walk or bike the **Seawall** (10 km loop around the park).
- Visit **Beaver Lake** and **Lost Lagoon** for birds and spring foliage.
- Check out **Totem Poles** at Brockton Point.
- Stop at **Vancouver Aquarium** (inside the park).

**Info & maps:**
- City of Vancouver – Stanley Park:  
  https://vancouver.ca/parks-recreation-culture/stanley-park.aspx  
- Vancouver Aquarium:  
  https://www.vanaqua.org/

---

## 2. Cherry Blossoms & Vancouver Cherry Blossom Festival

**Timing:** Typically early April, but varies by year.

**What to do:**
- Join events from the **Vancouver Cherry Blossom Festival** (concerts, guided walks, bike rides, “The Big Picnic” in David Lam Park some years).
- Self-guided blossom viewing in:
  - **Queen Elizabeth Park**
  - **Stanley Park**
  - **UBC campus**
  - Neighborhoods like **Kitsilano**, **Yaletown**, and **West End**

**Info & blossom maps:**
- Vancouver Cherry Blossom Festival:  
  https://www.vcbf.ca/  
- Blossom map:  
  https://www.vcbf.ca/blooming-now/neighbourhood-maps

---

## 3. Queen Elizabeth Park & Bloedel Conservatory

**Why spring?** Gardens are at their best; great city and mountain views on clear days.

**Highlights:**
- Quarry Garden and rose garden (roses peak later, but spring flowers are lovely).
- **Bloedel Conservatory** – tropical plants and free-flying birds in a domed greenhouse (nice backup if it’s raining).

**Info:**
- Queen Elizabeth Park:  
  https://vancouver.ca/parks-recreation-culture/queen-elizabeth-park.aspx  
- Bloedel Conservatory:  
  https://vancouver.ca/parks-recreation-culture/bloedel-conservatory.aspx

---

## 4. VanDusen Botanical Garden

**Why spring?** Rhododendrons, magnolias, cherry blossoms, and bulbs (tulips, daffodils) are in bloom.

**What to do:**
- Wander themed gardens (Japanese, Korean, Mediterranean, etc.).
- Seasonal events and plant sales in spring.

**Info:**
- VanDusen Botanical Garden:  
  https://vandusengarden.ca/

---

## 5. Granville Island Public Market

**Good in any weather; especially nice in mild spring temps.**

**What to do:**
- Browse the **Public Market** for local produce, baked goods, and lunch.
- Visit artisan shops and galleries in the former industrial buildings.
- Take a **False Creek ferry** ride for views of downtown and the mountains.

**Info:**
- Granville Island:  
  https://granvilleisland.com/  
- False Creek Ferries:  
  https://www.granvilleislandferries.bc.ca/  
- Aquabus:  
  https://theaquabus.com/

---

## 6. Seawall & City Cycling

**Why spring?** Comfortable temps and longer daylight; less crowded than summer.

**Ideas:**
- Rent bikes near **Denman Street** or **Coal Harbour** and ride:
  - Stanley Park Seawall
  - Around **False Creek** (Science World → Olympic Village → Granville Island)
- Or walk the shorter sections if you prefer.

**Info:**
- Vancouver Seawall overview:  
  https://vancouver.ca/parks-recreation-culture/seawall.aspx

---

## 7. Capilano Suspension Bridge Park or Lynn Canyon

**Why spring?** Lush green rainforest, full rivers and waterfalls from snowmelt.

**Capilano Suspension Bridge Park (paid, more developed):**
- Suspension bridge, treetop walkways, and cliffwalk.
- More touristy but very photogenic.

**Lynn Canyon Park (by donation/parking fees, more natural):**
- Suspension bridge, forest trails, waterfalls.
- Great if you prefer a less commercial feel.

**Info:**
- Capilano Suspension Bridge Park:  
  https://www.capbridge.com/  
- Lynn Canyon Park:  
  https://lynncanyon.ca/

---

## 8. Grouse Mountain – “The Peak of Vancouver”

**Spring specifics:**
- Early spring: still snow sports (skiing, snowshoeing) and winter scenery.
- Late spring: hiking trails start to open; **Grouse Grind** typically opens late spring/early summer depending on conditions.

**What to do:**
- Take the **Skyride** gondola for city and mountain views.
- Visit wildlife refuge (grizzly bears in season), lumberjack shows, and viewpoints.

**Info:**
- Grouse Mountain:  
  https://www.grousemountain.com/

---

## 9. UBC Campus: Museum of Anthropology Area & Beaches

**Note:** The Museum of Anthropology has been undergoing seismic upgrades; check status before you go.

**What to do:**
- Walk the UBC campus and Pacific Spirit Regional Park trails.
- Visit **Wreck Beach** (steep stairs, clothing-optional) or **Spanish Banks/Jericho Beach** for views of downtown and the North Shore mountains.
- If open: **Museum of Anthropology** for Indigenous art and architecture.

**Info:**
- Museum of Anthropology:  
  https://moa.ubc.ca/  
- Pacific Spirit Regional Park:  
  https://bcparks.ca/pacific-spirit-park/  
- Vancouver beaches:  
  https://vancouver.ca/parks-recreation-culture/beaches.aspx

---

## 10. Spring Festivals & Events

**Depending on your dates from Seattle, look for:**

- **Vancouver Cherry Blossom Festival** (April):  
  https://www.vcbf.ca/
- **Vancouver International Wine Festival** (often late Feb–early March):  
  https://vanwinefest.ca/
- **Vancouver Sun Run** (April) – big 10K run/walk:  
  https://vancouversunrun.com/
- **Vancouver International Children’s Festival** (late May/early June):  
  https://www.childrensfestival.ca/

Check dates each year; they shift slightly.

---

## 11. Food & Neighborhood Wandering

**Great spring neighborhoods to explore on foot:**
- **Gastown** – historic streets, restaurants, bars, shops.  
  Info: https://gastown.org/
- **Yaletown** – patios and restaurants, especially nice on mild evenings.  
  Info: https://yaletowninfo.com/
- **Commercial Drive** – cafés, Italian and global food, indie shops.  
- **Kitsilano** – West 4th Ave and Kits Beach area; good on a sunny spring day.

For restaurant ideas:
- Tourism Vancouver food & drink:  
  https://www.destinationvancouver.com/restaurants/

---

## 12. Easy Nature Trips from Vancouver (good for a Seattle weekend)

If you have a car:

- **Sea-to-Sky Highway to Squamish/Whistler**
  - **Shannon Falls** (short walk to a big waterfall).  
    Info: https://bcparks.ca/shannon-falls-park/
  - **Sea to Sky Gondola** (trails and viewpoints at the top).  
    Info: https://www.seatoskygondola.com/
- **Steveston Village (Richmond)** – historic fishing village, waterfront walks, seafood.  
  Info: https://www.visitrichmondbc.com/steveston/

---

## 13. Practical Notes from Seattle

- **Travel time:** ~2.5–3 hours driving from Seattle (plus border wait).  
  Border info: https://www.cbsa-asfc.gc.ca/do-rb/menu-eng.html
- **Weather:** Spring is variable—bring layers and a light rain jacket.  
  Forecast: https://weather.gc.ca/city/pages/bc-74_metric_e.html
- **Transit:** SkyTrain and buses are easy for most city sights.  
  TransLink trip planner: https://www.translink.ca/

---

If you share your exact spring dates and whether you’ll have a car, I can narrow this to a 1–2 day or 3–4 day itinerary tailored to you.

Full_Prompt: What are the best things to do in Vancouver in Spring? Give me sources for your answer where applicable.
Answer:
Here are some of the best things to do in Vancouver in spring (roughly March–May), with links so you can check details and current conditions from Seattle before you go.

---

## 1. Explore Stanley Park in Bloom

**Why spring?** Cherry blossoms, fresh greenery, and fewer summer crowds.

**Top activities:**
- Walk or bike the **Seawall** (10 km loop around the park).
- Visit **Beaver Lake** and **Lost Lagoon** for birds and spring foliage.
- Check out **Totem Poles** at Brockton Point.
- Stop at **Vancouver Aquarium** (inside the park).

**Info & maps:**
- City of Vancouver – Stanley Park:  
  https://vancouver.ca/parks-recreation-culture/stanley-park.aspx  
- Vancouver Aquarium:  
  https://www.vanaqua.org/

---

## 2. Cherry Blossoms & Vancouver Cherry Blossom Festival

**Timing:** Typically early April, but varies by year.

**What to do:**
- Join events from the **Vancouver Cherry Blossom Festival** (concerts, guided walks, bike rides, “The Big Picnic” in David Lam Park some years).
- Self-guided blossom viewing in:
  - **Queen Elizabeth Park**
  - **Stanley Park**
  - **UBC campus**
  - Neighborhoods like **Kitsilano**, **Yaletown**, and **West End**

**Info & blossom maps:**
- Vancouver Cherry Blossom Festival:  
  https://www.vcbf.ca/  
- Blossom map:  
  https://www.vcbf.ca/blooming-now/neighbourhood-maps

---

## 3. Queen Elizabeth Park & Bloedel Conservatory

**Why spring?** Gardens are at their best; great city and mountain views on clear days.

**Highlights:**
- Quarry Garden and rose garden (roses peak later, but spring flowers are lovely).
- **Bloedel Conservatory** – tropical plants and free-flying birds in a domed greenhouse (nice backup if it’s raining).

**Info:**
- Queen Elizabeth Park:  
  https://vancouver.ca/parks-recreation-culture/queen-elizabeth-park.aspx  
- Bloedel Conservatory:  
  https://vancouver.ca/parks-recreation-culture/bloedel-conservatory.aspx

---

## 4. VanDusen Botanical Garden

**Why spring?** Rhododendrons, magnolias, cherry blossoms, and bulbs (tulips, daffodils) are in bloom.

**What to do:**
- Wander themed gardens (Japanese, Korean, Mediterranean, etc.).
- Seasonal events and plant sales in spring.

**Info:**
- VanDusen Botanical Garden:  
  https://vandusengarden.ca/

---

## 5. Granville Island Public Market

**Good in any weather; especially nice in mild spring temps.**

**What to do:**
- Browse the **Public Market** for local produce, baked goods, and lunch.
- Visit artisan shops and galleries in the former industrial buildings.
- Take a **False Creek ferry** ride for views of downtown and the mountains.

**Info:**
- Granville Island:  
  https://granvilleisland.com/  
- False Creek Ferries:  
  https://www.granvilleislandferries.bc.ca/  
- Aquabus:  
  https://theaquabus.com/

---

## 6. Seawall & City Cycling

**Why spring?** Comfortable temps and longer daylight; less crowded than summer.

**Ideas:**
- Rent bikes near **Denman Street** or **Coal Harbour** and ride:
  - Stanley Park Seawall
  - Around **False Creek** (Science World → Olympic Village → Granville Island)
- Or walk the shorter sections if you prefer.

**Info:**
- Vancouver Seawall overview:  
  https://vancouver.ca/parks-recreation-culture/seawall.aspx

---

## 7. Capilano Suspension Bridge Park or Lynn Canyon

**Why spring?** Lush green rainforest, full rivers and waterfalls from snowmelt.

**Capilano Suspension Bridge Park (paid, more developed):**
- Suspension bridge, treetop walkways, and cliffwalk.
- More touristy but very photogenic.

**Lynn Canyon Park (by donation/parking fees, more natural):**
- Suspension bridge, forest trails, waterfalls.
- Great if you prefer a less commercial feel.

**Info:**
- Capilano Suspension Bridge Park:  
  https://www.capbridge.com/  
- Lynn Canyon Park:  
  https://lynncanyon.ca/

---

## 8. Grouse Mountain – “The Peak of Vancouver”

**Spring specifics:**
- Early spring: still snow sports (skiing, snowshoeing) and winter scenery.
- Late spring: hiking trails start to open; **Grouse Grind** typically opens late spring/early summer depending on conditions.

**What to do:**
- Take the **Skyride** gondola for city and mountain views.
- Visit wildlife refuge (grizzly bears in season), lumberjack shows, and viewpoints.

**Info:**
- Grouse Mountain:  
  https://www.grousemountain.com/

---

## 9. UBC Campus: Museum of Anthropology Area & Beaches

**Note:** The Museum of Anthropology has been undergoing seismic upgrades; check status before you go.

**What to do:**
- Walk the UBC campus and Pacific Spirit Regional Park trails.
- Visit **Wreck Beach** (steep stairs, clothing-optional) or **Spanish Banks/Jericho Beach** for views of downtown and the North Shore mountains.
- If open: **Museum of Anthropology** for Indigenous art and architecture.

**Info:**
- Museum of Anthropology:  
  https://moa.ubc.ca/  
- Pacific Spirit Regional Park:  
  https://bcparks.ca/pacific-spirit-park/  
- Vancouver beaches:  
  https://vancouver.ca/parks-recreation-culture/beaches.aspx

---

## 10. Spring Festivals & Events

**Depending on your dates from Seattle, look for:**

- **Vancouver Cherry Blossom Festival** (April):  
  https://www.vcbf.ca/
- **Vancouver International Wine Festival** (often late Feb–early March):  
  https://vanwinefest.ca/
- **Vancouver Sun Run** (April) – big 10K run/walk:  
  https://vancouversunrun.com/
- **Vancouver International Children’s Festival** (late May/early June):  
  https://www.childrensfestival.ca/

Check dates each year; they shift slightly.

---

## 11. Food & Neighborhood Wandering

**Great spring neighborhoods to explore on foot:**
- **Gastown** – historic streets, restaurants, bars, shops.  
  Info: https://gastown.org/
- **Yaletown** – patios and restaurants, especially nice on mild evenings.  
  Info: https://yaletowninfo.com/
- **Commercial Drive** – cafés, Italian and global food, indie shops.  
- **Kitsilano** – West 4th Ave and Kits Beach area; good on a sunny spring day.

For restaurant ideas:
- Tourism Vancouver food & drink:  
  https://www.destinationvancouver.com/restaurants/

---

## 12. Easy Nature Trips from Vancouver (good for a Seattle weekend)

If you have a car:

- **Sea-to-Sky Highway to Squamish/Whistler**
  - **Shannon Falls** (short walk to a big waterfall).  
    Info: https://bcparks.ca/shannon-falls-park/
  - **Sea to Sky Gondola** (trails and viewpoints at the top).  
    Info: https://www.seatoskygondola.com/
- **Steveston Village (Richmond)** – historic fishing village, waterfront walks, seafood.  
  Info: https://www.visitrichmondbc.com/steveston/

---

## 13. Practical Notes from Seattle

- **Travel time:** ~2.5–3 hours driving from Seattle (plus border wait).  
  Border info: https://www.cbsa-asfc.gc.ca/do-rb/menu-eng.html
- **Weather:** Spring is variable—bring layers and a light rain jacket.  
  Forecast: https://weather.gc.ca/city/pages/bc-74_metric_e.html
- **Transit:** SkyTrain and buses are easy for most city sights.  
  TransLink trip planner: https://www.translink.ca/

---

If you share your exact spring dates and whether you’ll have a car, I can narrow this to a 1–2 day or 3–4 day itinerary tailored to you.

- Blossom map:

---

## 3. Queen Elizabeth Park & Bloedel Conservatory

**Why spring?** Gardens are at their best; great city and mountain views on clear days.

**Highlights:**
- Quarry Garden and rose garden (roses peak later, but spring flowers are lovely).
- **Bloedel Conservatory** – tropical plants and free-flying birds in a domed greenhouse (nice backup if it’s raining).

## 4. VanDusen Botanical Garden

**Why spring?** Rhododendrons, magnolias, cherry blossoms, and bulbs (tulips, daffodils) are in bloom.

- Seasonal events and plant sales in spring.

## 5. Granville Island Public Market

**Good in any weather; especially nice in mild spring temps.**

**What to do:**

- Visit artisan shops and galleries in the former industrial buildings.
- Take a **False Creek ferry** ride for views of downtown and the mountains.

  - **Sea to Sky Gondola** (trails and viewpoints at the top).  
    Info: https://www.seatoskygondola.com/
- **Steveston Village (Richmond)** – historic fishing village, waterfront walks, seafood.  
  Info: https://www.visitrichmondbc.com/steveston/

  Border info: https://www.cbsa-asfc.gc.ca/do-rb/menu-eng.html
- **Weather:** Spring is variable—bring layers and a light rain jacket.

  - **Stanley Park**
  - **UBC campus**

Prompt: What are the best things to do in Vancouver in Spring?
Full_Prompt: What are the best things to do in Vancouver in Spring? Give me sources for your answer where applicable.
Answer:
Here are some of the best things to do in Vancouver in spring (roughly March–May), when cherry blossoms, mild weather, and longer days make the city especially good to explore. I’ll include official or reputable sources you can check for details and current info.

---

## 1. See Cherry Blossoms Around the City

**Why spring:** Late March–April is peak blossom season. Vancouver has over 40,000 cherry trees.

**Top spots:**
- **Queen Elizabeth Park** – Great views plus many cherry trees.  
  - Info: City of Vancouver – Queen Elizabeth Park  
    https://vancouver.ca/parks-recreation-culture/queen-elizabeth-park.aspx
- **Stanley Park (e.g., around the Rose Garden)**  
  - Info: Vancouver Board of Parks and Recreation – Stanley Park  
    https://vancouver.ca/parks-recreation-culture/stanley-park.aspx
- **West 22nd Avenue (Arbutus–Yew St area)** and **Yew St in Kitsilano** – classic blossom-lined residential streets.
- **Downtown & West End** – e.g., Burrard Station area, Nicola St.

**Festival:**  
- **Vancouver Cherry Blossom Festival** (usually April) – guided walks, bike rides, cultural events.  
  https://www.vcbf.ca/

---

## 2. Explore Stanley Park & the Seawall

**Why spring:** Fewer crowds than summer, greenery returning, often clear mountain views.

**What to do:**
- Walk or cycle the **Seawall** (10 km loop around the park).
- Visit **Totem Poles at Brockton Point**.
- Detour to **Beaver Lake** and **Lost Lagoon** for birdlife.

**Bike rentals:** Along Denman St near the park entrance (e.g., Spokes, Yes Cycle).

**Info:**  
Vancouver Park Board – Stanley Park  
https://vancouver.ca/parks-recreation-culture/stanley-park.aspx

---

## 3. Wander Granville Island

**Why spring:** Outdoor patios start opening, and it’s pleasant to stroll the waterfront.

**Highlights:**
- **Public Market** – local produce, seafood, baked goods.  
- **Artisan shops & galleries** in the Net Loft and Railspur Alley.  
- **Granville Island Brewing** and waterfront restaurants.

**Getting there:**  
- From downtown, take an **Aquabus** or **False Creek Ferry** for a short scenic ride.

**Info:**  
Granville Island official site  
https://granvilleisland.com/

---

## 4. Visit VanDusen Botanical Garden & Bloedel Conservatory

**Why spring:** Rhododendrons, magnolias, tulips, and cherry blossoms are in bloom.

- **VanDusen Botanical Garden** – 55-acre garden with themed areas and spring flower displays.  
  https://vandusengarden.org/
- **Bloedel Conservatory** (at Queen Elizabeth Park) – domed tropical garden with exotic plants and birds; good backup if it’s raining.  
  https://vancouver.ca/parks-recreation-culture/bloedel-conservatory.aspx

---

## 5. Stroll the Seawall from Yaletown to Olympic Village

**Why spring:** Comfortable temperatures for walking, and patios begin to open.

**Route idea:**
- Start in **Yaletown** (Canada Line: Yaletown–Roundhouse).
- Walk along **False Creek Seawall** past Science World to **Olympic Village**.
- Stop at cafés or breweries (e.g., in Olympic Village).

**Seawall info:**  
City of Vancouver – Seawall  
https://vancouver.ca/parks-recreation-culture/seawall.aspx

---

## 6. Day Trip to Capilano Suspension Bridge or Lynn Canyon

**Why spring:** Forests are lush, rivers are full, and it’s not peak tourist season yet.

### Capilano Suspension Bridge Park (North Vancouver)
- 137 m long suspension bridge, **Cliffwalk**, **Treetops Adventure**.  
- Free shuttle from downtown in peak seasons (check schedule).  
Info: https://www.capbridge.com/

### Lynn Canyon Park (North Vancouver)
- Free suspension bridge, forest trails, waterfalls.  
- Less commercial, more “local” feel.  
Info: District of North Vancouver – Lynn Canyon  
https://www.dnv.org/parks-recreation/lynn-canyon-park

---

## 7. Spring Skiing or Snow Activities (March–Early April)

From Vancouver you can still ski while enjoying spring in the city.

### Grouse Mountain
- Skiing/boarding (early spring), snowshoeing, and city views.  
- Later in spring, hiking trails and the **Grouse Grind** may open (check conditions).  
Info: https://www.grousemountain.com/

### Cypress Mountain & Mount Seymour
- Both offer spring skiing/boarding and snowshoeing, depending on snowpack.  
Cypress: https://cypressmountain.com/  
Mt Seymour: https://mtseymour.ca/

---

## 8. Explore Neighbourhoods: Gastown, Chinatown, Commercial Drive, Kitsilano

**Gastown**
- Historic cobblestone streets, **Steam Clock**, boutiques, bars.  
Tourism Vancouver – Gastown overview:  
https://www.destinationvancouver.com/vancouver/neighbourhoods/gastown/

**Chinatown**
- **Dr. Sun Yat-Sen Classical Chinese Garden** – especially pretty in spring.  
  https://vancouverchinesegarden.com/

**Commercial Drive (“The Drive”)**
- Cafés, Italian and global eateries, indie shops; nice for a relaxed afternoon.

**Kitsilano**
- Walk **Kits Beach** and West 4th Ave; good on a sunny spring day.

---

## 9. Visit Museums & Galleries (Great for Rainy Days)

Spring weather can be mixed, so indoor options are useful.

- **Museum of Anthropology (MOA)** at UBC – world-renowned Indigenous art and culture. (Note: undergoing seismic upgrades; check current status and partial openings.)  
  https://moa.ubc.ca/
- **Vancouver Art Gallery** – rotating exhibitions plus Canadian and Indigenous art.  
  https://www.vanartgallery.bc.ca/
- **Science World** – interactive science exhibits; good if you’re travelling with kids.  
  https://www.scienceworld.ca/

---

## 10. Hike Lower-Elevation Trails

Snow can linger at higher elevations, but many lower trails are great in spring.

**Ideas:**
- **Pacific Spirit Regional Park** (near UBC) – forest trails, usually snow-free.  
  https://www.metrovancouver.org/services/regional-parks/pacific-spirit-regional-park
- **Lighthouse Park** (West Vancouver) – old-growth forest and ocean viewpoints.  
  https://westvancouver.ca/parks-recreation/parks-trails/parks/lighthouse-park
- **Quarry Rock / Deep Cove** – classic short hike with inlet views (check for trail updates/closures).  
  Info via District of North Vancouver: https://www.dnv.org/parks-recreation

---

## 11. Attend Spring Events & Markets

Exact dates vary by year, so check closer to your trip:

- **Vancouver Cherry Blossom Festival** (April)  
  https://www.vcbf.ca/
- **Vancouver International Wine Festival** (often late Feb–early March)  
  https://vanwinefest.ca/
- **Farmers’ Markets** – many reopen or expand in spring (e.g., Riley Park, Trout Lake).  
  Vancouver Farmers Markets: https://eatlocal.org/

---

## 12. Take a Short Trip to Steveston or Bowen Island

**Steveston Village (Richmond)**
- Historic fishing village, **Gulf of Georgia Cannery National Historic Site**, waterfront walks, fish & chips.  
  https://www.pc.gc.ca/en/lhn-nhs/bc/georgia  
  Tourism Richmond – Steveston: https://www.visitrichmondbc.com/steveston-village/

**Bowen Island**
- 20-min ferry from Horseshoe Bay; good for easy hikes, cafés, and coastal views.  
  Bowen Island tourism: https://tourismbowenisland.com/

---

If you tell me your exact travel month, interests (e.g., food, hiking, art, nightlife), and how many days you’ll have, I can turn this into a focused spring itinerary with time estimates and transit tips from downtown.

Prompt: What are the best things to do in Vancouver in Spring?
Full_Prompt: What are the best things to do in Vancouver in Spring? Give me sources for your answer where applicable.
Answer:
Here are some of the best things to do in Vancouver in spring (roughly March–May), when cherry blossoms, mild weather, and longer days make the city especially good to explore. I’ll include official or reputable sources you can check for details and current info.

---

## 1. See Cherry Blossoms Around the City

**Why spring:** Late March–April is peak blossom season. Vancouver has over 40,000 cherry trees.

**Top spots:**
- **Queen Elizabeth Park** – Great views plus many cherry trees.  
  - Info: City of Vancouver – Queen Elizabeth Park  
    https://vancouver.ca/parks-recreation-culture/queen-elizabeth-park.aspx
- **Stanley Park (e.g., around the Rose Garden)**  
  - Info: Vancouver Board of Parks and Recreation – Stanley Park  
    https://vancouver.ca/parks-recreation-culture/stanley-park.aspx
- **West 22nd Avenue (Arbutus–Yew St area)** and **Yew St in Kitsilano** – classic blossom-lined residential streets.
- **Downtown & West End** – e.g., Burrard Station area, Nicola St.

**Festival:**  
- **Vancouver Cherry Blossom Festival** (usually April) – guided walks, bike rides, cultural events.  
  https://www.vcbf.ca/

---

## 2. Explore Stanley Park & the Seawall

**Why spring:** Fewer crowds than summer, greenery returning, often clear mountain views.

**What to do:**
- Walk or cycle the **Seawall** (10 km loop around the park).
- Visit **Totem Poles at Brockton Point**.
- Detour to **Beaver Lake** and **Lost Lagoon** for birdlife.

**Bike rentals:** Along Denman St near the park entrance (e.g., Spokes, Yes Cycle).

**Info:**  
Vancouver Park Board – Stanley Park  
https://vancouver.ca/parks-recreation-culture/stanley-park.aspx

---

## 3. Wander Granville Island

**Why spring:** Outdoor patios start opening, and it’s pleasant to stroll the waterfront.

**Highlights:**
- **Public Market** – local produce, seafood, baked goods.  
- **Artisan shops & galleries** in the Net Loft and Railspur Alley.  
- **Granville Island Brewing** and waterfront restaurants.

**Getting there:**  
- From downtown, take an **Aquabus** or **False Creek Ferry** for a short scenic ride.

**Info:**  
Granville Island official site  
https://granvilleisland.com/

---

## 4. Visit VanDusen Botanical Garden & Bloedel Conservatory

**Why spring:** Rhododendrons, magnolias, tulips, and cherry blossoms are in bloom.

- **VanDusen Botanical Garden** – 55-acre garden with themed areas and spring flower displays.  
  https://vandusengarden.org/
- **Bloedel Conservatory** (at Queen Elizabeth Park) – domed tropical garden with exotic plants and birds; good backup if it’s raining.  
  https://vancouver.ca/parks-recreation-culture/bloedel-conservatory.aspx

---

## 5. Stroll the Seawall from Yaletown to Olympic Village

**Why spring:** Comfortable temperatures for walking, and patios begin to open.

**Route idea:**
- Start in **Yaletown** (Canada Line: Yaletown–Roundhouse).
- Walk along **False Creek Seawall** past Science World to **Olympic Village**.
- Stop at cafés or breweries (e.g., in Olympic Village).

**Seawall info:**  
City of Vancouver – Seawall  
https://vancouver.ca/parks-recreation-culture/seawall.aspx

---

## 6. Day Trip to Capilano Suspension Bridge or Lynn Canyon

**Why spring:** Forests are lush, rivers are full, and it’s not peak tourist season yet.

### Capilano Suspension Bridge Park (North Vancouver)
- 137 m long suspension bridge, **Cliffwalk**, **Treetops Adventure**.  
- Free shuttle from downtown in peak seasons (check schedule).  
Info: https://www.capbridge.com/

### Lynn Canyon Park (North Vancouver)
- Free suspension bridge, forest trails, waterfalls.  
- Less commercial, more “local” feel.  
Info: District of North Vancouver – Lynn Canyon  
https://www.dnv.org/parks-recreation/lynn-canyon-park

---

## 7. Spring Skiing or Snow Activities (March–Early April)

From Vancouver you can still ski while enjoying spring in the city.

### Grouse Mountain
- Skiing/boarding (early spring), snowshoeing, and city views.  
- Later in spring, hiking trails and the **Grouse Grind** may open (check conditions).  
Info: https://www.grousemountain.com/

### Cypress Mountain & Mount Seymour
- Both offer spring skiing/boarding and snowshoeing, depending on snowpack.  
Cypress: https://cypressmountain.com/  
Mt Seymour: https://mtseymour.ca/

---

## 8. Explore Neighbourhoods: Gastown, Chinatown, Commercial Drive, Kitsilano

**Gastown**
- Historic cobblestone streets, **Steam Clock**, boutiques, bars.  
Tourism Vancouver – Gastown overview:  
https://www.destinationvancouver.com/vancouver/neighbourhoods/gastown/

**Chinatown**
- **Dr. Sun Yat-Sen Classical Chinese Garden** – especially pretty in spring.  
  https://vancouverchinesegarden.com/

**Commercial Drive (“The Drive”)**
- Cafés, Italian and global eateries, indie shops; nice for a relaxed afternoon.

**Kitsilano**
- Walk **Kits Beach** and West 4th Ave; good on a sunny spring day.

---

## 9. Visit Museums & Galleries (Great for Rainy Days)

Spring weather can be mixed, so indoor options are useful.

- **Museum of Anthropology (MOA)** at UBC – world-renowned Indigenous art and culture. (Note: undergoing seismic upgrades; check current status and partial openings.)  
  https://moa.ubc.ca/
