### 16. Just Sit Somewhere Scenic
If you want minimal planning, these are easy, low-stress spots:
- **Sunset at English Bay or Third Beach**
- **Benches along Coal Harbour** (near the Vancouver Convention Centre)
- **Olympic Village waterfront** (False Creek) – good for a quiet drink and people-watching.

- **Why it’s relaxing:** Forested trails close to the city but much quieter than Stanley Park.

### 6. English Bay, Kitsilano, and Jericho Beaches
- **Why it’s relaxing:** Calm water, wide beaches, and great sunsets over the mountains.
- **Vibes:**
  - **English Bay** – central, cafés nearby, great for sunset.
  - **Kits Beach** – more “local”, grassy areas, volleyball, seawall.
  - **Jericho & Locarno** – quieter, more open space, good for just sitting with a book.

### 10. Granville Island Public Market

### 11. Cafés & Bookstores
- **Why it’s relaxing:** Vancouver has a strong café culture and some great independent bookshops.

  https://moa.ubc.ca/  

---

### 13. Vancouver Art Gallery & Robson Square
- **Why it’s relaxing:** Calm galleries, then sit outside in Robson Square or a nearby café.
- **Info:**  
  https://www.vanartgallery.bc.ca/  

---

## Easy Day Trips for a Change of Pace

### 14. Bowen Island
- **Why it’s relaxing:** Small island, forest walks, cafés, and coves; feels far from the city but only a short ferry ride.
- **How:** Bus or drive to Horseshoe Bay, then walk-on ferry (~20 mins).
- **Info:**  
  https://www.tourismbowenisland.com/  

---

### 15. Sea-to-Sky Highway Lookouts (Squamish area)
- **Why it’s relaxing:** Scenic drive with short, easy stops.
- **Ideas:**
  - **Shannon Falls** – short walk to a big waterfall.  
    Info: https://bcparks.ca/shannon-falls-park/  
  - **Sea to Sky Gondola** – ride up, then gentle walks and viewpoints at the top.  
    Info: https://www.seatoskygondola.com/  

---

### 16. Just Sit Somewhere Scenic
If you want minimal planning, these are easy, low-stress spots:
- **Sunset at English Bay or Third Beach**
- **Benches along Coal Harbour** (near the Vancouver Convention Centre)
- **Olympic Village waterfront** (False Creek) – good for a quiet drink and people-watching.

### 2. Stanley Park Forest Trails & Beaches

  - **Second Beach** & **Third Beach** for sunset
- **Info:**  
  https://vancouver.ca/parks-recreation-culture/stanley-park-trails.aspx  

---

### 3. Queen Elizabeth Park & Bloedel Conservatory
- **Why it’s relaxing:** Beautiful gardens, city views, and a warm indoor conservatory with tropical plants and birds.

  - Bloedel Conservatory:  
    https://vancouver.ca/parks-recreation-culture/bloedel-conservatory.aspx  

---

### 4. VanDusen Botanical Garden
- **Why it’s relaxing:** Large, landscaped gardens with ponds, themed areas, and lots of quiet corners.
- **Tip:** Check seasonal events (e.g., spring blooms, autumn colours, Festival of Lights in December).
- **Info:**  
  https://vandusengarden.ca/  

---

- **Why it’s relaxing:** Forested trails close to the city but much quieter than Stanley Park.

- **Info:**

---

### 6. English Bay, Kitsilano, and Jericho Beaches
- **Why it’s relaxing:** Calm water, wide beaches, and great sunsets over the mountains.
- **Vibes:**
  - **English Bay** – central, cafés nearby, great for sunset.
  - **Kits Beach** – more “local”, grassy areas, volleyball, seawall.
  - **Jericho & Locarno** – quieter, more open space, good for just sitting with a book.

  https://www.scandinave.com/whistler/en/

### 10. Granville Island Public Market
- **Why it’s relaxing:** Indoor market with food stalls, bakeries, coffee, and waterfront seating.
- **Relaxing way to do it:** Grab something to eat, sit by the water, watch the boats and buskers.
- **Info:**  
  https://granvilleisland.com/public-market  

---

### 11. Cafés & Bookstores
- **Why it’s relaxing:** Vancouver has a strong café culture and some great independent bookshops.
- **Areas to wander:**
  - **Main Street (Mount Pleasant)** – indie shops, cafés, murals.
  - **Commercial Drive** – laid-back, lots of patios and coffee spots.
  - **Kitsilano (West 4th & Broadway)** – beachy, relaxed vibe.
- **Bookstores to consider:**
  - **MacLeod’s Books** (huge used bookstore):

  - **Massy Books** (Indigenous-owned, curated selection):

- **Info:**  
  https://moa.ubc.ca/  

---

### 13. Vancouver Art Gallery & Robson Square
- **Why it’s relaxing:** Calm galleries, then sit outside in Robson Square or a nearby café.
- **Info:**  
  https://www.vanartgallery.bc.ca/  

---

## Easy Day Trips for a Change of Pace

### 14. Bowen Island
- **Why it’s relaxing:** Small island, forest walks, cafés, and coves; feels far from the city but only a short ferry ride.
- **How:** Bus or drive to Horseshoe Bay, then walk-on ferry (~20 mins).
- **Info:**  
  https://www.tourismbowenisland.com/  

---

### 15. Sea-to-Sky Highway Lookouts (Squamish area)
- **Why it’s relaxing:** Scenic drive with short, easy stops.
- **Ideas:**
  - **Shannon Falls** – short walk to a big waterfall.  
    Info: https://bcparks.ca/shannon-falls-park/  
  - **Sea to Sky Gondola** – ride up, then gentle walks and viewpoints at the top.  
    Info: https://www.seatoskygondola.com/  

---

## Very Low-Effort Relaxation

### 16. Just Sit Somewhere Scenic
If you want minimal planning, these are easy, low-stress spots:
- **Sunset at English Bay or Third Beach**
- **Benches along Coal Harbour** (near the Vancouver Convention Centre)
- **Olympic Village waterfront** (False Creek) – good for a quiet drink and people-watching.

Prompt: Where are the best places to eat in Vancouver?
Full_Prompt: Where are the best places to eat in Vancouver? Give me sources for your answer where applicable.
Answer:
Here are some of Vancouver’s most consistently recommended places to eat, across different styles and budgets. I’ll group them by type and include sources you can check for up‑to‑date reviews, menus, and reservations.

---

## Top Overall / “Destination” Restaurants

### 1. **Published on Main** (Mount Pleasant)
Modern Canadian, hyper‑seasonal, creative tasting and à la carte.
- Frequently ranked among Canada’s best restaurants.
- Strong cocktails and wine program.

**Sources:**
- Canada’s 100 Best – regularly in top 5:  
  https://canadas100best.com/list/
- Michelin Guide Vancouver (Recommended):  
  https://guide.michelin.com/ca/en/british-columbia/ca-vancouver/restaurant/published-on-main
- Google Maps reviews:  
  https://maps.app.goo.gl/7x5v2pQp4xZ7P8dR8

---

### 2. **St. Lawrence** (Railtown / East of Gastown)
Quebecois/French bistro with rich, classic dishes in a cozy room.
- Known for set menus, pâtés, and hearty mains.

**Sources:**
- Michelin Guide – 1 Star:  
  https://guide.michelin.com/ca/en/british-columbia/ca-vancouver/restaurant/st-lawrence
- Canada’s 100 Best:  
  https://canadas100best.com/list/st-lawrence-2023/
- Google Maps:  
  https://maps.app.goo.gl/3Q8o4q7p7E2dQ2tE8

---

### 3. **Hawksworth Restaurant** (Downtown)
Upscale contemporary Canadian in the Rosewood Hotel Georgia.
- Refined but not overly fussy; good for a “special night out.”

**Sources:**
- Canada’s 100 Best:  
  https://canadas100best.com/list/hawksworth-restaurant-2023/
- Google Maps:  
  https://maps.app.goo.gl/5f1o9p9H1t4x1gkP7

---

### 4. **AnnaLena** (Kitsilano)
Modern Canadian tasting menus with playful plating and strong cocktails.

**Sources:**
- Michelin Guide – 1 Star:  
  https://guide.michelin.com/ca/en/british-columbia/ca-vancouver/restaurant/annalena
- Google Maps:  
  https://maps.app.goo.gl/7L3v2n1oQ4Z6Zp7P8

---

## Asian & Sushi (Vancouver’s Strongest Category)

### 5. **Miku** (Downtown Waterfront)
High‑end sushi with aburi (flame‑seared) specialties and harbour views.

**Sources:**
- Miku official site:  
  https://mikurestaurant.com/vancouver/
- Google Maps:  
  https://maps.app.goo.gl/7Q4Lx1pXq4q1pL7N8

---

### 6. **Tojo’s** (Fairview)
Long‑standing omakase institution by chef Hidekazu Tojo.
- Pricey, more old‑school, but iconic.

**Sources:**
- Tojo’s site:  
  https://tojos.com/
- Google Maps:  
  https://maps.app.goo.gl/1p7x4b2Qq2n7L5JH7

---

### 7. **Sushi Bar Maumi** (West End)
Tiny, traditional omakase counter; reservations essential.
- Focus on fish quality over decor.

**Sources:**
- Google Maps:  
  https://maps.app.goo.gl/2k8w2Zt5p1p5G3yK7
- Vancouver Magazine coverage:  
  https://www.vanmag.com/Eat-and-Drink

---

### 8. **Kissa Tanto** (Chinatown)
Italian‑Japanese fusion in a cool, retro space.
- Known for pasta, crudo, and cocktails.

**Sources:**
- Michelin Guide – 1 Star:  
  https://guide.michelin.com/ca/en/british-columbia/ca-vancouver/restaurant/kissa-tanto
- Canada’s 100 Best:  
  https://canadas100best.com/list/kissa-tanto-2023/

---

### 9. **Dynasty Seafood** (Cambie Village)
Classic Cantonese and dim sum; very popular with locals.

**Sources:**
- Google Maps:  
  https://maps.app.goo.gl/2b9o7s8N9B7V9x4E7
- Local coverage (Georgia Straight food section):  
  https://www.straight.com/food

---

### 10. **Peaceful Restaurant** (Multiple locations)
Northern Chinese (hand‑pulled noodles, cumin lamb, beef rolls).
- Casual, great value.

**Sources:**
- Peaceful site:  
  https://peacefulrestaurant.com/
- Google Maps (original Broadway location):  
  https://maps.app.goo.gl/7p5y3x2F1q8L9k6N7

---

## Casual Local Favourites

### 11. **Tacofino** (Multiple locations)
West Coast–style tacos and burritos; started as a Tofino food truck.

**Sources:**
- Tacofino site:  
  https://tacofino.com/
- Google Maps (Gastown location):

Small, cozy, and one of the city’s most acclaimed restaurants. Rich, classic French-Canadian dishes (tourtière, pâté en croûte, game, offal) with a refined touch. Reservations essential.
- Website: https://stlawrencerestaurant.com  
- Reviews/Lists:  
  - Canada’s 100 Best: https://canadas100best.com (St. Lawrence frequently ranks top 10)  
  - Michelin Guide Vancouver: https://guide.michelin.com/en/ca/british-columbia/vancouver

### **Published on Main** – Contemporary Canadian
Creative, seasonal tasting and à la carte menus with a strong focus on local ingredients. Frequently cited as one of Canada’s best restaurants.
- Website: https://publishedonmain.com  
- Canada’s 100 Best (often #1): https://canadas100best.com  
- Michelin Guide: https://guide.michelin.com/en/ca/british-columbia/vancouver

### **Hawksworth** – Modern Canadian / Fine Dining
Located in the Rosewood Hotel Georgia. Elegant room, polished service, and refined West Coast cuisine.
- Website: https://hawksworthrestaurant.com  
- Reviews:  
  - Vancouver Magazine Restaurant Awards: https://www.vanmag.com  
  - OpenTable: https://www.opentable.ca/hawksworth-restaurant

### **Miku** – High-End Sushi & Aburi
Known for aburi (flame-seared) sushi and a great waterfront location near Canada Place. Excellent for a nicer night out.
- Website: https://mikurestaurant.com  
- Michelin Guide listing: https://guide.michelin.com/en/ca/british-columbia/vancouver  
- Reviews: https://www.yelp.ca/biz/miku-vancouver

---

## 2. Sushi & Japanese (Vancouver’s Strong Suit)

### **Tojo’s** – Classic High-End Omakase
One of Vancouver’s original sushi institutions. Pricey, but a reference point for omakase in the city.
- Website: https://tojos.com  
- Reviews: https://www.yelp.ca/biz/tojos-restaurant-vancouver

### **Masayoshi** – Omakase-Only
Small, reservation-only omakase bar in Fraserhood. Focus on seasonal fish and traditional technique.
- Website: https://www.masayoshi.ca  
- Michelin Guide: https://guide.michelin.com/en/ca/british-columbia/vancouver

### **Sushi Bar Maumi** – Intimate Omakase
Tiny counter, strict rules (no phones, fixed seating times), but excellent fish quality and value for omakase.
- Info & reservations: https://www.exploretock.com/sushibarmaumi  
- Reviews: https://www.yelp.ca/biz/sushi-bar-maumi-vancouver

### **Kingyo / Guu / Raisu** – Izakaya
Lively Japanese tapas-style spots; great for sharing plates and drinks.
- Kingyo: https://www.kingyo-izakaya.ca  
- Raisu: https://www.raisu.ca  
- Guu (multiple locations): https://guu-izakaya.com  
- Local roundups: https://www.vancouverisawesome.com & https://dailyhive.com/vancouver

---

## 3. Chinese & Asian (Richmond + Vancouver)

### **Dynasty Seafood** – Dim Sum & Cantonese
Consistently recommended for high-quality dim sum and banquet-style dinners.
- Website: https://dynasty-seafood.com  
- Reviews: https://www.yelp.ca/biz/dynasty-seafood-restaurant-vancouver

### **Kirin** (Multiple Locations) – Dim Sum
Well-known local chain for classic Cantonese dim sum and seafood.
- Website: https://kirinrestaurants.com  
- Reviews: https://www.yelp.ca/search?find_desc=Kirin+Restaurant&find_loc=Vancouver%2C+BC

### **Richmond Food Scene (short SkyTrain ride from downtown)**
For some of the best Chinese and Asian food in North America, head to Richmond:
- **HK BBQ Master** – Roast meats under a parking garage, cult favorite.  
  - Reviews: https://www.yelp.ca/biz/hk-bbq-master-richmond  
- **Shanghai River** – Xiao long bao and Shanghainese dishes.  
  - Reviews: https://www.yelp.ca/biz/shanghai-river-richmond  
- **Parker Place / Aberdeen Centre food courts** – Great for casual eats.  
  - Overview: https://www.tourismrichmond.com/blog

Tourism Richmond’s food guide:  
- https://www.tourismrichmond.com/restaurants

---

## 4. Casual West Coast & Brunch

### **Jam Café** – Big Comfort-Brunch
Hearty, creative brunch plates; expect a line.
- Website: https://jamcafes.com  
- Reviews: https://www.yelp.ca/biz/jam-cafe-vancouver

### **Café Medina** – Brunch with a Mediterranean Twist
Known for waffles, lavender latte, and brunch dishes with North African/Mediterranean flavors.
- Website: https://www.medinacafe.com  
- Reviews: https://www.yelp.ca/biz/caf%C3%A9-medina-vancouver

### **Chambar** – Belgian / Mediterranean
Great for brunch or dinner; mussels, tagines, and a strong beer list.
- Website: https://www.chambar.com  
- Reviews: https://www.yelp.ca/biz/chambar-vancouver

### **Nuba** – Lebanese
Fresh, healthy plates (falafel, lamb, mezze). Several locations; good for vegetarians.
- Website: https://www.nuba.ca  
- Reviews: https://www.yelp.ca/search?find_desc=Nuba&find_loc=Vancouver%2C+BC

---

## 5. Seafood & Views

### **Blue Water Cafe** – Seafood & Raw Bar
Upscale Yaletown spot with a strong raw bar and sustainable seafood focus.
- Website: https://www.bluewatercafe.net  
- Reviews: https://www.yelp.ca/biz/blue-water-cafe-vancouver

### **Ancora** – Nikkei / Peruvian-Japanese Seafood
Seafood-focused with Japanese and Peruvian influences; locations in False Creek and Ambleside (West Van).
- Website: https://ancoradining.com  
- Reviews: https://www.yelp.ca/search?find_desc=Ancora&find_loc=Vancouver%2C+BC

### **The Sandbar** – Granville Island
More casual, but great for a drink and seafood with a view of False Creek.
- Website: https://www.vancouverdine.com/sandbar  
- Reviews: https://www.yelp.ca/biz/the-sandbar-seafood-restaurant-vancouver

---

## 6. Casual, Cheap(er), & Local Favorites

### **Tacofino** – Tacos & Burritos
Started as a Tofino food truck; now multiple locations. Good for casual, West Coast–style tacos.
- Website: https://tacofino.com  
- Reviews: https://www.yelp.ca/search?find_desc=Tacofino&find_loc=Vancouver%2C+BC

### **Meat & Bread** – Sandwiches
Famous porchetta sandwich; quick, satisfying lunch.
- Website: https://meatandbread.com  
- Reviews: https://www.yelp.ca/biz/meat-and-bread-vancouver-3

### **Vij’s / Rangoli** – Indian
Vij’s is a long-standing upscale Indian restaurant with inventive dishes; Rangoli next door is more casual.
- Website: https://vijs.ca  
- Reviews: https://www.yelp.ca/biz/vijs-vancouver

### **Marutama Ramen / Danbo / Kintaro** – Ramen
Vancouver has a strong ramen scene; these are frequently recommended:
- Marutama: https://www.marutama.ca  
- Danbo: https://ramendanbo.com  
- Kintaro: reviews at https://www.yelp.ca/biz/kintaro-ramen-vancouver

---

## 7. Coffee & Sweets

### **Revolver** – Coffee
Serious coffee program in Gastown; rotating roasters and tasting flights.
- Website: https://revolvercoffee.ca  
- Reviews: https://www.yelp.ca/biz/revolver-vancouver

### **49th Parallel & Lucky’s Doughnuts**
Excellent coffee and very good doughnuts.
- Website: https://49thcoffee.com  
- Reviews: https://www.yelp.ca/search?find_desc=49th+Parallel&find_loc=Vancouver%2C+BC

### **Thomas Haas** – Pastry & Chocolate
Top-tier patisserie and chocolates; worth the trip if you like desserts.
- Website: https://thomashaas.com  
- Reviews: https://www.yelp.ca/biz/thomas-haas-fine-chocolates-and-patisserie-vancouver

---

## Good Aggregated Sources

To cross-check and find more spots by neighborhood or cuisine:

- **Michelin Guide Vancouver**:  
  https://guide.michelin.com/en/ca/british-columbia/vancouver  
- **Canada’s 100 Best Restaurants** (filter for Vancouver):  
  https://canadas100best.com  
- **Tourism Vancouver (Destination Vancouver) restaurant listings**:  
  https://www.destinationvancouver.com/restaurants  
- **Local media roundups**:  
  - Vancouver Magazine: https://www.vanmag.com  
  - Daily Hive Dished: https://dailyhive.com/vancouver/food  
  - Vancouver Is Awesome: https://www.vancouverisawesome.com

---

---

## 1. Iconic & Upscale

### **St. Lawrence** – Québécois / French
Small, cozy, and one of the city’s most acclaimed restaurants. Rich, classic French-Canadian dishes (tourtière, pâté en croûte, game, offal) with a refined touch. Reservations essential.
- Website: https://stlawrencerestaurant.com  
- Reviews/Lists:  
  - Canada’s 100 Best: https://canadas100best.com (St. Lawrence frequently ranks top 10)  
  - Michelin Guide Vancouver: https://guide.michelin.com/en/ca/british-columbia/vancouver

### **Published on Main** – Contemporary Canadian
Creative, seasonal tasting and à la carte menus with a strong focus on local ingredients. Frequently cited as one of Canada’s best restaurants.
- Website: https://publishedonmain.com  
- Canada’s 100 Best (often #1): https://canadas100best.com  
- Michelin Guide: https://guide.michelin.com/en/ca/british-columbia/vancouver

### **Hawksworth** – Modern Canadian / Fine Dining
Located in the Rosewood Hotel Georgia. Elegant room, polished service, and refined West Coast cuisine.
- Website: https://hawksworthrestaurant.com  
- Reviews:  
  - Vancouver Magazine Restaurant Awards: https://www.vanmag.com  
  - OpenTable: https://www.opentable.ca/hawksworth-restaurant

### **Miku** – High-End Sushi & Aburi
Known for aburi (flame-seared) sushi and a great waterfront location near Canada Place. Excellent for a nicer night out.
- Website: https://mikurestaurant.com  
- Michelin Guide listing: https://guide.michelin.com/en/ca/british-columbia/vancouver  
- Reviews: https://www.yelp.ca/biz/miku-vancouver

---

## 2. Sushi & Japanese (Vancouver’s Strong Suit)

### **Tojo’s** – Classic High-End Omakase
One of Vancouver’s original sushi institutions. Pricey, but a reference point for omakase in the city.
- Website: https://tojos.com  
- Reviews: https://www.yelp.ca/biz/tojos-restaurant-vancouver

### **Masayoshi** – Omakase-Only
Small, reservation-only omakase bar in Fraserhood. Focus on seasonal fish and traditional technique.
- Website: https://www.masayoshi.ca  
- Michelin Guide: https://guide.michelin.com/en/ca/british-columbia/vancouver

### **Sushi Bar Maumi** – Intimate Omakase
Tiny counter, strict rules (no phones, fixed seating times), but excellent fish quality and value for omakase.
- Info & reservations: https://www.exploretock.com/sushibarmaumi  
- Reviews: https://www.yelp.ca/biz/sushi-bar-maumi-vancouver

### **Kingyo / Guu / Raisu** – Izakaya
Lively Japanese tapas-style spots; great for sharing plates and drinks.
- Kingyo: https://www.kingyo-izakaya.ca  
- Raisu: https://www.raisu.ca  
- Guu (multiple locations): https://guu-izakaya.com  
- Local roundups: https://www.vancouverisawesome.com & https://dailyhive.com/vancouver

---

## 3. Chinese & Asian (Richmond + Vancouver)

### **Dynasty Seafood** – Dim Sum & Cantonese
Consistently recommended for high-quality dim sum and banquet-style dinners.
- Website: https://dynasty-seafood.com  
- Reviews: https://www.yelp.ca/biz/dynasty-seafood-restaurant-vancouver

### **Kirin** (Multiple Locations) – Dim Sum
Well-known local chain for classic Cantonese dim sum and seafood.
- Website: https://kirinrestaurants.com  
- Reviews: https://www.yelp.ca/search?find_desc=Kirin+Restaurant&find_loc=Vancouver%2C+BC

### **Richmond Food Scene (short SkyTrain ride from downtown)**
For some of the best Chinese and Asian food in North America, head to Richmond:
- **HK BBQ Master** – Roast meats under a parking garage, cult favorite.  
  - Reviews: https://www.yelp.ca/biz/hk-bbq-master-richmond  
- **Shanghai River** – Xiao long bao and Shanghainese dishes.  
  - Reviews: https://www.yelp.ca/biz/shanghai-river-richmond  
- **Parker Place / Aberdeen Centre food courts** – Great for casual eats.  
  - Overview: https://www.tourismrichmond.com/blog

Tourism Richmond’s food guide:  
- https://www.tourismrichmond.com/restaurants

---

## 4. Casual West Coast & Brunch

### **Jam Café** – Big Comfort-Brunch
Hearty, creative brunch plates; expect a line.
- Website: https://jamcafes.com  
- Reviews: https://www.yelp.ca/biz/jam-cafe-vancouver

### **Café Medina** – Brunch with a Mediterranean Twist
Known for waffles, lavender latte, and brunch dishes with North African/Mediterranean flavors.
- Website: https://www.medinacafe.com  
- Reviews: https://www.yelp.ca/biz/caf%C3%A9-medina-vancouver

### **Chambar** – Belgian / Mediterranean
Great for brunch or dinner; mussels, tagines, and a strong beer list.
- Website: https://www.chambar.com  
- Reviews: https://www.yelp.ca/biz/chambar-vancouver

### **Nuba** – Lebanese
Fresh, healthy plates (falafel, lamb, mezze). Several locations; good for vegetarians.
- Website: https://www.nuba.ca  
- Reviews: https://www.yelp.ca/search?find_desc=Nuba&find_loc=Vancouver%2C+BC

---

## 5. Seafood & Views

### **Blue Water Cafe** – Seafood & Raw Bar
Upscale Yaletown spot with a strong raw bar and sustainable seafood focus.
- Website: https://www.bluewatercafe.net  
- Reviews: https://www.yelp.ca/biz/blue-water-cafe-vancouver

### **Ancora** – Nikkei / Peruvian-Japanese Seafood
Seafood-focused with Japanese and Peruvian influences; locations in False Creek and Ambleside (West Van).
- Website: https://ancoradining.com  
- Reviews: https://www.yelp.ca/search?find_desc=Ancora&find_loc=Vancouver%2C+BC

### **The Sandbar** – Granville Island
More casual, but great for a drink and seafood with a view of False Creek.
- Website: https://www.vancouverdine.com/sandbar  
- Reviews: https://www.yelp.ca/biz/the-sandbar-seafood-restaurant-vancouver

---

## 6. Casual, Cheap(er), & Local Favorites

### **Tacofino** – Tacos & Burritos
Started as a Tofino food truck; now multiple locations. Good for casual, West Coast–style tacos.
- Website: https://tacofino.com  
- Reviews: https://www.yelp.ca/search?find_desc=Tacofino&find_loc=Vancouver%2C+BC

### **Meat & Bread** – Sandwiches
Famous porchetta sandwich; quick, satisfying lunch.
- Website: https://meatandbread.com  
- Reviews: https://www.yelp.ca/biz/meat-and-bread-vancouver-3

### **Vij’s / Rangoli** – Indian
Vij’s is a long-standing upscale Indian restaurant with inventive dishes; Rangoli next door is more casual.
- Website: https://vijs.ca  
- Reviews: https://www.yelp.ca/biz/vijs-vancouver

### **Marutama Ramen / Danbo / Kintaro** – Ramen
Vancouver has a strong ramen scene; these are frequently recommended:
- Marutama: https://www.marutama.ca  
- Danbo: https://ramendanbo.com  
- Kintaro: reviews at https://www.yelp.ca/biz/kintaro-ramen-vancouver

### **Revolver** – Coffee
Serious coffee program in Gastown; rotating roasters and tasting flights.

- Reviews: https://www.yelp.ca/biz/revolver-vancouver

### **49th Parallel & Lucky’s Doughnuts**
Excellent coffee and very good doughnuts.
- Website: https://49thcoffee.com  
- Reviews: https://www.yelp.ca/search?find_desc=49th+Parallel&find_loc=Vancouver%2C+BC

### **Thomas Haas** – Pastry & Chocolate
Top-tier patisserie and chocolates; worth the trip if you like desserts.
- Website: https://thomashaas.com  
- Reviews: https://www.yelp.ca/biz/thomas-haas-fine-chocolates-and-patisserie-vancouver

- Michelin Guide: https://guide.michelin.com/en/ca/british-columbia/vancouver

### **Hawksworth** – Modern Canadian / Fine Dining
Located in the Rosewood Hotel Georgia. Elegant room, polished service, and refined West Coast cuisine.
- Website: https://hawksworthrestaurant.com  
- Reviews:  
  - Vancouver Magazine Restaurant Awards: https://www.vanmag.com  
  - OpenTable: https://www.opentable.ca/hawksworth-restaurant

### **Miku** – High-End Sushi & Aburi
Known for aburi (flame-seared) sushi and a great waterfront location near Canada Place. Excellent for a nicer night out.
- Website: https://mikurestaurant.com  
- Michelin Guide listing: https://guide.michelin.com/en/ca/british-columbia/vancouver  
- Reviews: https://www.yelp.ca/biz/miku-vancouver

## 2. Sushi & Japanese (Vancouver’s Strong Suit)

One of Vancouver’s original sushi institutions. Pricey, but a reference point for omakase in the city.
- Website: https://tojos.com  
- Reviews: https://www.yelp.ca/biz/tojos-restaurant-vancouver

### **Masayoshi** – Omakase-Only
Small, reservation-only omakase bar in Fraserhood. Focus on seasonal fish and traditional technique.
- Website: https://www.masayoshi.ca  
- Michelin Guide: https://guide.michelin.com/en/ca/british-columbia/vancouver

### **Sushi Bar Maumi** – Intimate Omakase
Tiny counter, strict rules (no phones, fixed seating times), but excellent fish quality and value for omakase.
- Info & reservations: https://www.exploretock.com/sushibarmaumi  
- Reviews: https://www.yelp.ca/biz/sushi-bar-maumi-vancouver

### **Kingyo / Guu / Raisu** – Izakaya
Lively Japanese tapas-style spots; great for sharing plates and drinks.
- Kingyo: https://www.kingyo-izakaya.ca  
- Raisu: https://www.raisu.ca  
- Guu (multiple locations): https://guu-izakaya.com  
- Local roundups: https://www.vancouverisawesome.com & https://dailyhive.com/vancouver

---

## 3. Chinese & Asian (Richmond + Vancouver)

Consistently recommended for high-quality dim sum and banquet-style dinners.

- Reviews: https://www.yelp.ca/biz/dynasty-seafood-restaurant-vancouver

Well-known local chain for classic Cantonese dim sum and seafood.
- Website: https://kirinrestaurants.com  
- Reviews: https://www.yelp.ca/search?find_desc=Kirin+Restaurant&find_loc=Vancouver%2C+BC

For some of the best Chinese and Asian food in North America, head to Richmond:
- **HK BBQ Master** – Roast meats under a parking garage, cult favorite.

- **Shanghai River** – Xiao long bao and Shanghainese dishes.

- Reviews: https://www.yelp.ca/biz/jam-cafe-vancouver

Known for waffles, lavender latte, and brunch dishes with North African/Mediterranean flavors.

- Reviews: https://www.yelp.ca/biz/caf%C3%A9-medina-vancouver

Great for brunch or dinner; mussels, tagines, and a strong beer list.

Fresh, healthy plates (falafel, lamb, mezze). Several locations; good for vegetarians.

- Reviews: https://www.yelp.ca/search?find_desc=Nuba&find_loc=Vancouver%2C+BC

Small, cozy, and one of the city’s most acclaimed restaurants. Rich, classic French-Canadian dishes (tourtière, pâté en croûte, game, offal) with a refined touch. Reservations essential.

- Reviews/Lists:  
  - Canada’s 100 Best: https://canadas100best.com (St. Lawrence frequently ranks top 10)  
  - Michelin Guide Vancouver: https://guide.michelin.com/en/ca/british-columbia/vancouver

Creative, seasonal tasting and à la carte menus with a strong focus on local ingredients. Frequently cited as one of Canada’s best restaurants.
- Website: https://publishedonmain.com  
- Canada’s 100 Best (often #1): https://canadas100best.com  
- Michelin Guide: https://guide.michelin.com/en/ca/british-columbia/vancouver

### **Hawksworth** – Modern Canadian / Fine Dining
Located in the Rosewood Hotel Georgia. Elegant room, polished service, and refined West Coast cuisine.
- Website: https://hawksworthrestaurant.com  
- Reviews:  
  - Vancouver Magazine Restaurant Awards: https://www.vanmag.com  
  - OpenTable: https://www.opentable.ca/hawksworth-restaurant

### **Miku** – High-End Sushi & Aburi
Known for aburi (flame-seared) sushi and a great waterfront location near Canada Place. Excellent for a nicer night out.
- Website: https://mikurestaurant.com  
- Michelin Guide listing: https://guide.michelin.com/en/ca/british-columbia/vancouver  
- Reviews: https://www.yelp.ca/biz/miku-vancouver

---

## 2. Sushi & Japanese (Vancouver’s Strong Suit)

One of Vancouver’s original sushi institutions. Pricey, but a reference point for omakase in the city.
- Website: https://tojos.com  
- Reviews: https://www.yelp.ca/biz/tojos-restaurant-vancouver

### **Masayoshi** – Omakase-Only
Small, reservation-only omakase bar in Fraserhood. Focus on seasonal fish and traditional technique.
- Website: https://www.masayoshi.ca  
- Michelin Guide: https://guide.michelin.com/en/ca/british-columbia/vancouver

### **Sushi Bar Maumi** – Intimate Omakase
Tiny counter, strict rules (no phones, fixed seating times), but excellent fish quality and value for omakase.
- Info & reservations: https://www.exploretock.com/sushibarmaumi  
- Reviews: https://www.yelp.ca/biz/sushi-bar-maumi-vancouver

### **Kingyo / Guu / Raisu** – Izakaya
Lively Japanese tapas-style spots; great for sharing plates and drinks.
- Kingyo: https://www.kingyo-izakaya.ca  
- Raisu: https://www.raisu.ca  
- Guu (multiple locations): https://guu-izakaya.com  
- Local roundups: https://www.vancouverisawesome.com & https://dailyhive.com/vancouver

Consistently recommended for high-quality dim sum and banquet-style dinners.

Well-known local chain for classic Cantonese dim sum and seafood.

- Michelin Guide: https://guide.michelin.com/en/ca/british-columbia/vancouver

### **Hawksworth** – Modern Canadian / Fine Dining
Located in the Rosewood Hotel Georgia. Elegant room, polished service, and refined West Coast cuisine.
- Website: https://hawksworthrestaurant.com  
- Reviews:  
  - Vancouver Magazine Restaurant Awards: https://www.vanmag.com  
  - OpenTable: https://www.opentable.ca/hawksworth-restaurant

### **Miku** – High-End Sushi & Aburi
Known for aburi (flame-seared) sushi and a great waterfront location near Canada Place. Excellent for a nicer night out.
- Website: https://mikurestaurant.com  
- Michelin Guide listing: https://guide.michelin.com/en/ca/british-columbia/vancouver  
- Reviews: https://www.yelp.ca/biz/miku-vancouver

- Website: https://tojos.com

### **Masayoshi** – Omakase-Only
Small, reservation-only omakase bar in Fraserhood. Focus on seasonal fish and traditional technique.
- Website: https://www.masayoshi.ca  
- Michelin Guide: https://guide.michelin.com/en/ca/british-columbia/vancouver

### **Sushi Bar Maumi** – Intimate Omakase
Tiny counter, strict rules (no phones, fixed seating times), but excellent fish quality and value for omakase.
- Info & reservations: https://www.exploretock.com/sushibarmaumi  
- Reviews: https://www.yelp.ca/biz/sushi-bar-maumi-vancouver

### **Kingyo / Guu / Raisu** – Izakaya
Lively Japanese tapas-style spots; great for sharing plates and drinks.
- Kingyo: https://www.kingyo-izakaya.ca  
- Raisu: https://www.raisu.ca

Located in the Rosewood Hotel Georgia. Elegant room, polished service, and refined West Coast cuisine.

- Reviews:  
  - Vancouver Magazine Restaurant Awards: https://www.vanmag.com

### **Miku** – High-End Sushi & Aburi
Known for aburi (flame-seared) sushi and a great waterfront location near Canada Place. Excellent for a nicer night out.

- Reviews: https://www.yelp.ca/biz/miku-vancouver

Tiny counter, strict rules (no phones, fixed seating times), but excellent fish quality and value for omakase.

- Reviews: https://www.yelp.ca/biz/sushi-bar-maumi-vancouver

Prompt: Where are the best places to eat in Vancouver?

Answer:

---

## 1. Iconic & Upscale

### **St. Lawrence** – Québécois / French
Small, cozy, and one of the city’s most acclaimed restaurants. Rich, classic French-Canadian dishes (tourtière, pâté en croûte, game, offal) with a refined touch. Reservations essential.
- Website: https://stlawrencerestaurant.com  
- Reviews/Lists:  
  - Canada’s 100 Best: https://canadas100best.com (St. Lawrence frequently ranks top 10)  
  - Michelin Guide Vancouver: https://guide.michelin.com/en/ca/british-columbia/vancouver

### **Published on Main** – Contemporary Canadian
Creative, seasonal tasting and à la carte menus with a strong focus on local ingredients. Frequently cited as one of Canada’s best restaurants.
- Website: https://publishedonmain.com  
- Canada’s 100 Best (often #1): https://canadas100best.com  
- Michelin Guide: https://guide.michelin.com/en/ca/british-columbia/vancouver

### **Hawksworth** – Modern Canadian / Fine Dining
Located in the Rosewood Hotel Georgia. Elegant room, polished service, and refined West Coast cuisine.
- Website: https://hawksworthrestaurant.com  
- Reviews:  
  - Vancouver Magazine Restaurant Awards: https://www.vanmag.com  
  - OpenTable: https://www.opentable.ca/hawksworth-restaurant

### **Miku** – High-End Sushi & Aburi
Known for aburi (flame-seared) sushi and a great waterfront location near Canada Place. Excellent for a nicer night out.
- Website: https://mikurestaurant.com  
- Michelin Guide listing: https://guide.michelin.com/en/ca/british-columbia/vancouver  
- Reviews: https://www.yelp.ca/biz/miku-vancouver

---

## 2. Sushi & Japanese (Vancouver’s Strong Suit)

One of Vancouver’s original sushi institutions. Pricey, but a reference point for omakase in the city.
- Website: https://tojos.com  
- Reviews: https://www.yelp.ca/biz/tojos-restaurant-vancouver

### **Masayoshi** – Omakase-Only
Small, reservation-only omakase bar in Fraserhood. Focus on seasonal fish and traditional technique.
- Website: https://www.masayoshi.ca  
- Michelin Guide: https://guide.michelin.com/en/ca/british-columbia/vancouver

### **Sushi Bar Maumi** – Intimate Omakase
Tiny counter, strict rules (no phones, fixed seating times), but excellent fish quality and value for omakase.
- Info & reservations: https://www.exploretock.com/sushibarmaumi  
- Reviews: https://www.yelp.ca/biz/sushi-bar-maumi-vancouver

### **Kingyo / Guu / Raisu** – Izakaya
Lively Japanese tapas-style spots; great for sharing plates and drinks.
- Kingyo: https://www.kingyo-izakaya.ca  
- Raisu: https://www.raisu.ca  
- Guu (multiple locations): https://guu-izakaya.com  
- Local roundups: https://www.vancouverisawesome.com & https://dailyhive.com/vancouver

---

## 1. Iconic & Upscale

### **St. Lawrence** – Québécois / French
Small, cozy, and one of the city’s most acclaimed restaurants. Rich, classic French-Canadian dishes (tourtière, pâté en croûte, game, offal) with a refined touch. Reservations essential.
- Website: https://stlawrencerestaurant.com  
- Reviews/Lists:  
  - Canada’s 100 Best: https://canadas100best.com (St. Lawrence frequently ranks top 10)  
  - Michelin Guide Vancouver: https://guide.michelin.com/en/ca/british-columbia/vancouver

### **Published on Main** – Contemporary Canadian
Creative, seasonal tasting and à la carte menus with a strong focus on local ingredients. Frequently cited as one of Canada’s best restaurants.
- Website: https://publishedonmain.com  
- Canada’s 100 Best (often #1): https://canadas100best.com  
- Michelin Guide: https://guide.michelin.com/en/ca/british-columbia/vancouver

### **Hawksworth** – Modern Canadian / Fine Dining
Located in the Rosewood Hotel Georgia. Elegant room, polished service, and refined West Coast cuisine.
- Website: https://hawksworthrestaurant.com  
- Reviews:  
  - Vancouver Magazine Restaurant Awards: https://www.vanmag.com  
  - OpenTable: https://www.opentable.ca/hawksworth-restaurant

### **Miku** – High-End Sushi & Aburi
Known for aburi (flame-seared) sushi and a great waterfront location near Canada Place. Excellent for a nicer night out.
- Website: https://mikurestaurant.com  
- Michelin Guide listing: https://guide.michelin.com/en/ca/british-columbia/vancouver  
- Reviews: https://www.yelp.ca/biz/miku-vancouver

Small, reservation-only omakase bar in Fraserhood. Focus on seasonal fish and traditional technique.

Tiny counter, strict rules (no phones, fixed seating times), but excellent fish quality and value for omakase.

- Reviews: https://www.yelp.ca/biz/sushi-bar-maumi-vancouver

One of Vancouver’s original sushi institutions. Pricey, but a reference point for omakase in the city.

- Reviews: https://www.yelp.ca/biz/tojos-restaurant-vancouver

### **Masayoshi** – Omakase-Only
Small, reservation-only omakase bar in Fraserhood. Focus on seasonal fish and traditional technique.
- Website: https://www.masayoshi.ca  
- Michelin Guide: https://guide.michelin.com/en/ca/british-columbia/vancouver

### **Sushi Bar Maumi** – Intimate Omakase
Tiny counter, strict rules (no phones, fixed seating times), but excellent fish quality and value for omakase.
- Info & reservations: https://www.exploretock.com/sushibarmaumi  
- Reviews: https://www.yelp.ca/biz/sushi-bar-maumi-vancouver

### **Kingyo / Guu / Raisu** – Izakaya
Lively Japanese tapas-style spots; great for sharing plates and drinks.
- Kingyo: https://www.kingyo-izakaya.ca  
- Raisu: https://www.raisu.ca  
- Guu (multiple locations): https://guu-izakaya.com

Consistently recommended for high-quality dim sum and banquet-style dinners.

- Reviews: https://www.yelp.ca/biz/dynasty-seafood-restaurant-vancouver

### **Kirin** (Multiple Locations) – Dim Sum
Well-known local chain for classic Cantonese dim sum and seafood.

For some of the best Chinese and Asian food in North America, head to Richmond:

Known for waffles, lavender latte, and brunch dishes with North African/Mediterranean flavors.

### **Hawksworth** – Modern Canadian / Fine Dining
Located in the Rosewood Hotel Georgia. Elegant room, polished service, and refined West Coast cuisine.

- Reviews:

Known for aburi (flame-seared) sushi and a great waterfront location near Canada Place. Excellent for a nicer night out.

Full_Prompt: Where are the best places to eat in Vancouver? Give me sources for your answer where applicable.
Answer:
Here’s a curated list of standout places to eat in Vancouver, grouped by type. I’ll include links and sources so you can dig deeper or check current menus and hours.

---

## 1. Iconic & Upscale

### **St. Lawrence** – Québécois / French
Small, cozy, and one of the city’s most acclaimed restaurants. Rich, classic French-Canadian dishes (tourtière, pâté en croûte, game, offal) with a refined touch. Reservations essential.
- Website: https://stlawrencerestaurant.com  
- Reviews/Lists:  
  - Canada’s 100 Best: https://canadas100best.com (St. Lawrence frequently ranks top 10)  
  - Michelin Guide Vancouver: https://guide.michelin.com/en/ca/british-columbia/vancouver

### **Published on Main** – Contemporary Canadian
Creative, seasonal tasting and à la carte menus with a strong focus on local ingredients. Frequently cited as one of Canada’s best restaurants.
- Website: https://publishedonmain.com  
- Canada’s 100 Best (often #1): https://canadas100best.com  
- Michelin Guide: https://guide.michelin.com/en/ca/british-columbia/vancouver

### **Hawksworth** – Modern Canadian / Fine Dining
Located in the Rosewood Hotel Georgia. Elegant room, polished service, and refined West Coast cuisine.
- Website: https://hawksworthrestaurant.com  
- Reviews:  
  - Vancouver Magazine Restaurant Awards: https://www.vanmag.com  
  - OpenTable: https://www.opentable.ca/hawksworth-restaurant

### **Miku** – High-End Sushi & Aburi
Known for aburi (flame-seared) sushi and a great waterfront location near Canada Place. Excellent for a nicer night out.
- Website: https://mikurestaurant.com  
- Michelin Guide listing: https://guide.michelin.com/en/ca/british-columbia/vancouver  
- Reviews: https://www.yelp.ca/biz/miku-vancouver

---

## 2. Sushi & Japanese (Vancouver’s Strong Suit)

### **Tojo’s** – Classic High-End Omakase
One of Vancouver’s original sushi institutions. Pricey, but a reference point for omakase in the city.
- Website: https://tojos.com  
- Reviews: https://www.yelp.ca/biz/tojos-restaurant-vancouver

### **Masayoshi** – Omakase-Only
Small, reservation-only omakase bar in Fraserhood. Focus on seasonal fish and traditional technique.
- Website: https://www.masayoshi.ca  
- Michelin Guide: https://guide.michelin.com/en/ca/british-columbia/vancouver

### **Sushi Bar Maumi** – Intimate Omakase
Tiny counter, strict rules (no phones, fixed seating times), but excellent fish quality and value for omakase.
- Info & reservations: https://www.exploretock.com/sushibarmaumi  
- Reviews: https://www.yelp.ca/biz/sushi-bar-maumi-vancouver

### **Kingyo / Guu / Raisu** – Izakaya
Lively Japanese tapas-style spots; great for sharing plates and drinks.
- Kingyo: https://www.kingyo-izakaya.ca  
- Raisu: https://www.raisu.ca  
- Guu (multiple locations): https://guu-izakaya.com  
- Local roundups: https://www.vancouverisawesome.com & https://dailyhive.com/vancouver

---

## 3. Chinese & Asian (Richmond + Vancouver)

### **Dynasty Seafood** – Dim Sum & Cantonese
Consistently recommended for high-quality dim sum and banquet-style dinners.
- Website: https://dynasty-seafood.com  
- Reviews: https://www.yelp.ca/biz/dynasty-seafood-restaurant-vancouver

### **Kirin** (Multiple Locations) – Dim Sum
Well-known local chain for classic Cantonese dim sum and seafood.
- Website: https://kirinrestaurants.com  
- Reviews: https://www.yelp.ca/search?find_desc=Kirin+Restaurant&find_loc=Vancouver%2C+BC

### **Richmond Food Scene (short SkyTrain ride from downtown)**
For some of the best Chinese and Asian food in North America, head to Richmond:
- **HK BBQ Master** – Roast meats under a parking garage, cult favorite.  
  - Reviews: https://www.yelp.ca/biz/hk-bbq-master-richmond  
- **Shanghai River** – Xiao long bao and Shanghainese dishes.  
  - Reviews: https://www.yelp.ca/biz/shanghai-river-richmond  
- **Parker Place / Aberdeen Centre food courts** – Great for casual eats.  
  - Overview: https://www.tourismrichmond.com/blog

Tourism Richmond’s food guide:  
- https://www.tourismrichmond.com/restaurants

---

## 4. Casual West Coast & Brunch

### **Jam Café** – Big Comfort-Brunch
Hearty, creative brunch plates; expect a line.
- Website: https://jamcafes.com  
- Reviews: https://www.yelp.ca/biz/jam-cafe-vancouver

### **Café Medina** – Brunch with a Mediterranean Twist
Known for waffles, lavender latte, and brunch dishes with North African/Mediterranean flavors.
- Website: https://www.medinacafe.com  
- Reviews: https://www.yelp.ca/biz/caf%C3%A9-medina-vancouver

### **Chambar** – Belgian / Mediterranean
Great for brunch or dinner; mussels, tagines, and a strong beer list.
- Website: https://www.chambar.com  
- Reviews: https://www.yelp.ca/biz/chambar-vancouver

### **Nuba** – Lebanese
Fresh, healthy plates (falafel, lamb, mezze). Several locations; good for vegetarians.
- Website: https://www.nuba.ca  
- Reviews: https://www.yelp.ca/search?find_desc=Nuba&find_loc=Vancouver%2C+BC

---

## 5. Seafood & Views

### **Blue Water Cafe** – Seafood & Raw Bar
Upscale Yaletown spot with a strong raw bar and sustainable seafood focus.
- Website: https://www.bluewatercafe.net  
- Reviews: https://www.yelp.ca/biz/blue-water-cafe-vancouver

### **Ancora** – Nikkei / Peruvian-Japanese Seafood
Seafood-focused with Japanese and Peruvian influences; locations in False Creek and Ambleside (West Van).
- Website: https://ancoradining.com  
- Reviews: https://www.yelp.ca/search?find_desc=Ancora&find_loc=Vancouver%2C+BC

### **The Sandbar** – Granville Island
More casual, but great for a drink and seafood with a view of False Creek.
- Website: https://www.vancouverdine.com/sandbar  
- Reviews: https://www.yelp.ca/biz/the-sandbar-seafood-restaurant-vancouver

---

## 6. Casual, Cheap(er), & Local Favorites

### **Tacofino** – Tacos & Burritos
Started as a Tofino food truck; now multiple locations. Good for casual, West Coast–style tacos.
- Website: https://tacofino.com  
- Reviews: https://www.yelp.ca/search?find_desc=Tacofino&find_loc=Vancouver%2C+BC

### **Meat & Bread** – Sandwiches
Famous porchetta sandwich; quick, satisfying lunch.
- Website: https://meatandbread.com  
- Reviews: https://www.yelp.ca/biz/meat-and-bread-vancouver-3

### **Vij’s / Rangoli** – Indian
Vij’s is a long-standing upscale Indian restaurant with inventive dishes; Rangoli next door is more casual.
- Website: https://vijs.ca  
- Reviews: https://www.yelp.ca/biz/vijs-vancouver

### **Marutama Ramen / Danbo / Kintaro** – Ramen
Vancouver has a strong ramen scene; these are frequently recommended:
- Marutama: https://www.marutama.ca  
- Danbo: https://ramendanbo.com  
- Kintaro: reviews at https://www.yelp.ca/biz/kintaro-ramen-vancouver

---

## 7. Coffee & Sweets

### **Revolver** – Coffee
Serious coffee program in Gastown; rotating roasters and tasting flights.
- Website: https://revolvercoffee.ca  
- Reviews: https://www.yelp.ca/biz/revolver-vancouver

### **49th Parallel & Lucky’s Doughnuts**
Excellent coffee and very good doughnuts.
- Website: https://49thcoffee.com  
- Reviews: https://www.yelp.ca/search?find_desc=49th+Parallel&find_loc=Vancouver%2C+BC

### **Thomas Haas** – Pastry & Chocolate
Top-tier patisserie and chocolates; worth the trip if you like desserts.
- Website: https://thomashaas.com  
- Reviews: https://www.yelp.ca/biz/thomas-haas-fine-chocolates-and-patisserie-vancouver

---

## Good Aggregated Sources

To cross-check and find more spots by neighborhood or cuisine:

- **Michelin Guide Vancouver**:  
  https://guide.michelin.com/en/ca/british-columbia/vancouver  
- **Canada’s 100 Best Restaurants** (filter for Vancouver):  
  https://canadas100best.com  
- **Tourism Vancouver (Destination Vancouver) restaurant listings**:  
  https://www.destinationvancouver.com/restaurants  
- **Local media roundups**:  
  - Vancouver Magazine: https://www.vanmag.com  
  - Daily Hive Dished: https://dailyhive.com/vancouver/food  
  - Vancouver Is Awesome: https://www.vancouverisawesome.com

---

If you tell me your budget, preferred neighborhoods, and whether you’ll have a car (you’re coming from LA, so that can matter for Richmond), I can narrow this down to a short, tailored hit list.

- Reviews: https://www.yelp.ca/biz/miku-vancouver

Small, reservation-only omakase bar in Fraserhood. Focus on seasonal fish and traditional technique.

Known for waffles, lavender latte, and brunch dishes with North African/Mediterranean flavors.

- Reviews/Lists:

Creative, seasonal tasting and à la carte menus with a strong focus on local ingredients. Frequently cited as one of Canada’s best restaurants.
- Website: https://publishedonmain.com  
- Canada’s 100 Best (often #1): https://canadas100best.com  
- Michelin Guide: https://guide.michelin.com/en/ca/british-columbia/vancouver

### **Hawksworth** – Modern Canadian / Fine Dining
Located in the Rosewood Hotel Georgia. Elegant room, polished service, and refined West Coast cuisine.
- Website: https://hawksworthrestaurant.com  
- Reviews:  
  - Vancouver Magazine Restaurant Awards: https://www.vanmag.com  
  - OpenTable: https://www.opentable.ca/hawksworth-restaurant

### **Miku** – High-End Sushi & Aburi
Known for aburi (flame-seared) sushi and a great waterfront location near Canada Place. Excellent for a nicer night out.
- Website: https://mikurestaurant.com  
- Michelin Guide listing: https://guide.michelin.com/en/ca/british-columbia/vancouver  
- Reviews: https://www.yelp.ca/biz/miku-vancouver

---

## 2. Sushi & Japanese (Vancouver’s Strong Suit)

### **Tojo’s** – Classic High-End Omakase
One of Vancouver’s original sushi institutions. Pricey, but a reference point for omakase in the city.
- Website: https://tojos.com  
- Reviews: https://www.yelp.ca/biz/tojos-restaurant-vancouver

### **Masayoshi** – Omakase-Only
Small, reservation-only omakase bar in Fraserhood. Focus on seasonal fish and traditional technique.
- Website: https://www.masayoshi.ca  
- Michelin Guide: https://guide.michelin.com/en/ca/british-columbia/vancouver

### **Sushi Bar Maumi** – Intimate Omakase
Tiny counter, strict rules (no phones, fixed seating times), but excellent fish quality and value for omakase.
- Info & reservations: https://www.exploretock.com/sushibarmaumi  
- Reviews: https://www.yelp.ca/biz/sushi-bar-maumi-vancouver

### **Kingyo / Guu / Raisu** – Izakaya
Lively Japanese tapas-style spots; great for sharing plates and drinks.
- Kingyo: https://www.kingyo-izakaya.ca  
- Raisu: https://www.raisu.ca  
- Guu (multiple locations): https://guu-izakaya.com  
- Local roundups: https://www.vancouverisawesome.com & https://dailyhive.com/vancouver

---

## 3. Chinese & Asian (Richmond + Vancouver)

### **Dynasty Seafood** – Dim Sum & Cantonese
Consistently recommended for high-quality dim sum and banquet-style dinners.
- Website: https://dynasty-seafood.com  
- Reviews: https://www.yelp.ca/biz/dynasty-seafood-restaurant-vancouver

### **Kirin** (Multiple Locations) – Dim Sum
Well-known local chain for classic Cantonese dim sum and seafood.
- Website: https://kirinrestaurants.com  
- Reviews: https://www.yelp.ca/search?find_desc=Kirin+Restaurant&find_loc=Vancouver%2C+BC

### **Richmond Food Scene (short SkyTrain ride from downtown)**
For some of the best Chinese and Asian food in North America, head to Richmond:
- **HK BBQ Master** – Roast meats under a parking garage, cult favorite.  
  - Reviews: https://www.yelp.ca/biz/hk-bbq-master-richmond  
- **Shanghai River** – Xiao long bao and Shanghainese dishes.  
  - Reviews: https://www.yelp.ca/biz/shanghai-river-richmond

Tourism Richmond’s food guide:  
- https://www.tourismrichmond.com/restaurants

## 4. Casual West Coast & Brunch

### **Jam Café** – Big Comfort-Brunch
Hearty, creative brunch plates; expect a line.
- Website: https://jamcafes.com  
- Reviews: https://www.yelp.ca/biz/jam-cafe-vancouver

### **Café Medina** – Brunch with a Mediterranean Twist
Known for waffles, lavender latte, and brunch dishes with North African/Mediterranean flavors.
- Website: https://www.medinacafe.com  
- Reviews: https://www.yelp.ca/biz/caf%C3%A9-medina-vancouver

### **Chambar** – Belgian / Mediterranean
Great for brunch or dinner; mussels, tagines, and a strong beer list.
- Website: https://www.chambar.com  
- Reviews: https://www.yelp.ca/biz/chambar-vancouver

### **Nuba** – Lebanese
Fresh, healthy plates (falafel, lamb, mezze). Several locations; good for vegetarians.
- Website: https://www.nuba.ca  
- Reviews: https://www.yelp.ca/search?find_desc=Nuba&find_loc=Vancouver%2C+BC

## 5. Seafood & Views

Upscale Yaletown spot with a strong raw bar and sustainable seafood focus.

- Reviews: https://www.yelp.ca/biz/blue-water-cafe-vancouver

### **Ancora** – Nikkei / Peruvian-Japanese Seafood
Seafood-focused with Japanese and Peruvian influences; locations in False Creek and Ambleside (West Van).

- Reviews:  
  - Vancouver Magazine Restaurant Awards: https://www.vanmag.com

### **Miku** – High-End Sushi & Aburi
Known for aburi (flame-seared) sushi and a great waterfront location near Canada Place. Excellent for a nicer night out.
- Website: https://mikurestaurant.com  
- Michelin Guide listing: https://guide.michelin.com/en/ca/british-columbia/vancouver  
- Reviews: https://www.yelp.ca/biz/miku-vancouver

## 2. Sushi & Japanese (Vancouver’s Strong Suit)

One of Vancouver’s original sushi institutions. Pricey, but a reference point for omakase in the city.

- Reviews: https://www.yelp.ca/biz/tojos-restaurant-vancouver

### **Masayoshi** – Omakase-Only
Small, reservation-only omakase bar in Fraserhood. Focus on seasonal fish and traditional technique.
- Website: https://www.masayoshi.ca  
- Michelin Guide: https://guide.michelin.com/en/ca/british-columbia/vancouver

### **Sushi Bar Maumi** – Intimate Omakase
Tiny counter, strict rules (no phones, fixed seating times), but excellent fish quality and value for omakase.
- Info & reservations: https://www.exploretock.com/sushibarmaumi  
- Reviews: https://www.yelp.ca/biz/sushi-bar-maumi-vancouver

Lively Japanese tapas-style spots; great for sharing plates and drinks.
- Kingyo: https://www.kingyo-izakaya.ca  
- Raisu: https://www.raisu.ca

- Reviews/Lists:  
  - Canada’s 100 Best: https://canadas100best.com (St. Lawrence frequently ranks top 10)

- Canada’s 100 Best (often #1): https://canadas100best.com  
- Michelin Guide: https://guide.michelin.com/en/ca/british-columbia/vancouver

### **Hawksworth** – Modern Canadian / Fine Dining
Located in the Rosewood Hotel Georgia. Elegant room, polished service, and refined West Coast cuisine.
- Website: https://hawksworthrestaurant.com  
- Reviews:  
  - Vancouver Magazine Restaurant Awards: https://www.vanmag.com  
  - OpenTable: https://www.opentable.ca/hawksworth-restaurant

### **Miku** – High-End Sushi & Aburi
Known for aburi (flame-seared) sushi and a great waterfront location near Canada Place. Excellent for a nicer night out.
- Website: https://mikurestaurant.com  
- Michelin Guide listing: https://guide.michelin.com/en/ca/british-columbia/vancouver  
- Reviews: https://www.yelp.ca/biz/miku-vancouver

### **Masayoshi** – Omakase-Only
Small, reservation-only omakase bar in Fraserhood. Focus on seasonal fish and traditional technique.
- Website: https://www.masayoshi.ca  
- Michelin Guide: https://guide.michelin.com/en/ca/british-columbia/vancouver

### **Sushi Bar Maumi** – Intimate Omakase
Tiny counter, strict rules (no phones, fixed seating times), but excellent fish quality and value for omakase.
- Info & reservations: https://www.exploretock.com/sushibarmaumi  
- Reviews: https://www.yelp.ca/biz/sushi-bar-maumi-vancouver

### **Kingyo / Guu / Raisu** – Izakaya
Lively Japanese tapas-style spots; great for sharing plates and drinks.
- Kingyo: https://www.kingyo-izakaya.ca  
- Raisu: https://www.raisu.ca  
- Guu (multiple locations): https://guu-izakaya.com

Small, cozy, and one of the city’s most acclaimed restaurants. Rich, classic French-Canadian dishes (tourtière, pâté en croûte, game, offal) with a refined touch. Reservations essential.

- Reviews/Lists:

Creative, seasonal tasting and à la carte menus with a strong focus on local ingredients. Frequently cited as one of Canada’s best restaurants.

- Michelin Guide: https://guide.michelin.com/en/ca/british-columbia/vancouver

### **Hawksworth** – Modern Canadian / Fine Dining
Located in the Rosewood Hotel Georgia. Elegant room, polished service, and refined West Coast cuisine.
- Website: https://hawksworthrestaurant.com  
- Reviews:  
  - Vancouver Magazine Restaurant Awards: https://www.vanmag.com  
  - OpenTable: https://www.opentable.ca/hawksworth-restaurant

### **Miku** – High-End Sushi & Aburi
Known for aburi (flame-seared) sushi and a great waterfront location near Canada Place. Excellent for a nicer night out.

- Reviews: https://www.yelp.ca/biz/miku-vancouver

Small, reservation-only omakase bar in Fraserhood. Focus on seasonal fish and traditional technique.
- Website: https://www.masayoshi.ca  
- Michelin Guide: https://guide.michelin.com/en/ca/british-columbia/vancouver

Tiny counter, strict rules (no phones, fixed seating times), but excellent fish quality and value for omakase.

- Reviews: https://www.yelp.ca/biz/sushi-bar-maumi-vancouver

- **Why go:** Frequently ranked among Canada’s top restaurants; hyper-seasonal, inventive plates, strong cocktails.
- **Try:** Whatever’s seasonal; tasting-style ordering is best.
- **Info & reviews:**
  - Website: https://www.publishedonmain.com  
  - Michelin Guide: https://guide.michelin.com/en/british-columbia/ca-vancouver/restaurant/published-on-main  
  - Reviews: https://www.yelp.com/biz/published-on-main-vancouver  

---

- **Why go:** Longtime upscale staple in the Rosewood Hotel Georgia; polished service, refined but approachable menu.
- **Try:** Tasting menu or chef’s seasonal mains.
- **Info & reviews:**
  - Website: https://hawksworthrestaurant.com  
  - Reviews: https://www.yelp.com/biz/hawksworth-restaurant-vancouver  

---

## 2. Sushi & Japanese (Vancouver’s strong suit)

### **Miku** – Aburi (flame-seared) Sushi
- **Why go:** Famous for aburi oshi (pressed, flame-seared sushi); waterfront views near Canada Place.
- **Try:** Salmon oshi, Miku roll, kaisen sashimi.
- **Info & reviews:**
  - Website: https://mikurestaurant.com  
  - Reviews: https://www.yelp.com/biz/miku-vancouver  

---

### **Minami** – Aburi Sushi in Yaletown
- **Why go:** Sister restaurant to Miku; similar style in a trendier neighborhood.
- **Try:** Aburi oshi sampler, specialty rolls, cocktails.
- **Info & reviews:**
  - Website: https://minamirestaurant.com  
  - Reviews: https://www.yelp.com/biz/minami-restaurant-vancouver  

---

### **Tojo’s** – High-End Omakase
- **Why go:** One of Vancouver’s original sushi institutions; omakase-focused, chef-driven.
- **Try:** Omakase experience at the bar if budget allows.
- **Info & reviews:**
  - Website: https://tojos.com  
  - Reviews: https://www.yelp.com/biz/tojos-restaurant-vancouver  

---

### **Sushi by Scratch** – Omakase (West Side)
- **Why go:** Intimate, set-course omakase imported from the US “Scratch” group; theatrical and high quality.
- **Info & reviews:**
  - Website: https://www.scratchrestaurants.com/sushi-by-scratch-vancouver  
  - Reviews: https://www.yelp.com/biz/sushi-by-scratch-vancouver  

---

- **Why go:** Frequently ranked among Canada’s top restaurants; hyper-seasonal, inventive plates, strong cocktails.
- **Try:** Whatever’s seasonal; tasting-style ordering is best.
- **Info & reviews:**
  - Website: https://www.publishedonmain.com  
  - Michelin Guide: https://guide.michelin.com/en/british-columbia/ca-vancouver/restaurant/published-on-main  
  - Reviews: https://www.yelp.com/biz/published-on-main-vancouver  

---

- **Why go:** Longtime upscale staple in the Rosewood Hotel Georgia; polished service, refined but approachable menu.
- **Try:** Tasting menu or chef’s seasonal mains.

  - Website: https://hawksworthrestaurant.com  
  - Reviews: https://www.yelp.com/biz/hawksworth-restaurant-vancouver  

---

## 2. Sushi & Japanese (Vancouver’s strong suit)

### **Miku** – Aburi (flame-seared) Sushi
- **Why go:** Famous for aburi oshi (pressed, flame-seared sushi); waterfront views near Canada Place.
- **Try:** Salmon oshi, Miku roll, kaisen sashimi.
- **Info & reviews:**
  - Website: https://mikurestaurant.com  
  - Reviews: https://www.yelp.com/biz/miku-vancouver  

---

### **Minami** – Aburi Sushi in Yaletown
- **Why go:** Sister restaurant to Miku; similar style in a trendier neighborhood.
- **Try:** Aburi oshi sampler, specialty rolls, cocktails.
- **Info & reviews:**
  - Website: https://minamirestaurant.com  
  - Reviews: https://www.yelp.com/biz/minami-restaurant-vancouver  

---

- **Why go:** One of Vancouver’s original sushi institutions; omakase-focused, chef-driven.
- **Try:** Omakase experience at the bar if budget allows.
- **Info & reviews:**
  - Website: https://tojos.com  
  - Reviews: https://www.yelp.com/biz/tojos-restaurant-vancouver  

---

- **Why go:** Intimate, set-course omakase imported from the US “Scratch” group; theatrical and high quality.
- **Info & reviews:**
  - Website: https://www.scratchrestaurants.com/sushi-by-scratch-vancouver

### **St. Lawrence** – Québécois / French
- **Why go:** Widely considered one of Vancouver’s very best restaurants; rich, comforting French-Canadian cooking with serious technique.
- **Try:** Tourtière, pâté en croûte, daily plats du jour.
- **Info & reviews:**
  - Website: https://stlawrencerestaurant.com  
  - Michelin Guide: https://guide.michelin.com/en/british-columbia/ca-vancouver/restaurant/st-lawrence

---

### **Published on Main** – Contemporary Canadian
- **Why go:** Frequently ranked among Canada’s top restaurants; hyper-seasonal, inventive plates, strong cocktails.
- **Try:** Whatever’s seasonal; tasting-style ordering is best.
- **Info & reviews:**
  - Website: https://www.publishedonmain.com  
  - Michelin Guide: https://guide.michelin.com/en/british-columbia/ca-vancouver/restaurant/published-on-main  
  - Reviews: https://www.yelp.com/biz/published-on-main-vancouver  

---

### **Hawksworth** – Modern Canadian / Fine Dining
- **Why go:** Longtime upscale staple in the Rosewood Hotel Georgia; polished service, refined but approachable menu.
- **Try:** Tasting menu or chef’s seasonal mains.
- **Info & reviews:**
  - Website: https://hawksworthrestaurant.com  
  - Reviews: https://www.yelp.com/biz/hawksworth-restaurant-vancouver  

---

## 2. Sushi & Japanese (Vancouver’s strong suit)

### **Miku** – Aburi (flame-seared) Sushi
- **Why go:** Famous for aburi oshi (pressed, flame-seared sushi); waterfront views near Canada Place.
- **Try:** Salmon oshi, Miku roll, kaisen sashimi.
- **Info & reviews:**
  - Website: https://mikurestaurant.com  
  - Reviews: https://www.yelp.com/biz/miku-vancouver  

---

### **Minami** – Aburi Sushi in Yaletown
- **Why go:** Sister restaurant to Miku; similar style in a trendier neighborhood.
- **Try:** Aburi oshi sampler, specialty rolls, cocktails.
- **Info & reviews:**
  - Website: https://minamirestaurant.com  
  - Reviews: https://www.yelp.com/biz/minami-restaurant-vancouver  

---

### **Tojo’s** – High-End Omakase
- **Why go:** One of Vancouver’s original sushi institutions; omakase-focused, chef-driven.
- **Try:** Omakase experience at the bar if budget allows.
- **Info & reviews:**
  - Website: https://tojos.com  
  - Reviews: https://www.yelp.com/biz/tojos-restaurant-vancouver  

---

### **Sushi by Scratch** – Omakase (West Side)
- **Why go:** Intimate, set-course omakase imported from the US “Scratch” group; theatrical and high quality.
- **Info & reviews:**
  - Website: https://www.scratchrestaurants.com/sushi-by-scratch-vancouver  
  - Reviews: https://www.yelp.com/biz/sushi-by-scratch-vancouver  

---

Prompt: Where are the best places to eat in Vancouver?
Full_Prompt: Where are the best places to eat in Vancouver? Give me sources for your answer where applicable.
Answer:
Here are some standout places to eat in Vancouver, with a focus on spots that are consistently recommended by critics and locals. I’ll group them by type and include sources you can check for up‑to‑date details and reviews.

---

## Top Overall / “Must‑Try” Restaurants

### 1. **Published on Main** – Modern Canadian
- **Why go:** Frequently cited as one of Canada’s best restaurants; inventive, seasonal, West Coast–driven menu.
- **Neighborhood:** Mount Pleasant
- **What to expect:** Tasting-menu feel without being overly formal; strong cocktails and wine list.
- **Sources:**
  - Canada’s 100 Best (often top-ranked):  
    https://canadas100best.com
  - Official site: https://www.publishedonmain.com

---

### 2. **St. Lawrence** – Quebecois / French
- **Why go:** Elevated Quebecois comfort food with French technique; very highly rated nationally.
- **Neighborhood:** Railtown / East of Gastown
- **What to expect:** Rich, hearty dishes (tourtière, pâté, foie gras), intimate room; reservations essential.
- **Sources:**
  - Canada’s 100 Best: https://canadas100best.com
  - Official site: https://stlawrencerestaurant.com

---

### 3. **AnnaLena** – Contemporary Canadian
- **Why go:** Creative tasting menus, playful plating, strong wine pairings; Michelin-starred.
- **Neighborhood:** Kitsilano
- **What to expect:** Refined but relaxed; great for a special night out.
- **Sources:**
  - Michelin Guide Vancouver: https://guide.michelin.com
  - Official site: https://www.annalenayvr.com

---

## Asian & Sushi (Vancouver’s Strongest Category)

### 4. **Miku** – Sushi / Aburi (seared) Omakase
- **Why go:** Famous for aburi (flame-seared) sushi; waterfront views by Canada Place.
- **Neighborhood:** Downtown / Waterfront
- **What to expect:** Polished service, great for lunch or dinner; pricier but consistent.
- **Sources:**
  - Official site: https://mikurestaurant.com
  - Vancouver Magazine review: https://www.vanmag.com

---

### 5. **Tojo’s** – High-End Sushi
- **Why go:** One of Vancouver’s original omakase institutions; chef Tojo is a local legend.
- **Neighborhood:** Fairview (Broadway)
- **What to expect:** Omakase-focused, traditional with some creative twists; expensive but iconic.
- **Sources:**
  - Official site: https://tojos.com
  - Michelin Guide listing: https://guide.michelin.com

---

### 6. **Kingyo** – Izakaya
- **Why go:** Lively Japanese small plates; consistently popular with locals.
- **Neighborhood:** West End (Denman St.)
- **What to expect:** Shared plates, good sake list, energetic atmosphere.
- **Sources:**
  - Official site: https://www.kingyo-izakaya.ca
  - Google Maps reviews for current feedback.

---

### 7. **Dynasty Seafood** – Dim Sum & Cantonese
- **Why go:** One of the city’s go‑to spots for dim sum and banquet-style Cantonese.
- **Neighborhood:** South Granville
- **What to expect:** Classic carts replaced by menu ordering; great seafood and dumplings.
- **Sources:**
  - Vancouver Sun / local coverage: https://vancouversun.com
  - Google Maps / Yelp for recent reviews.

---

### 8. **Kissa Tanto** – Japanese–Italian Fusion
- **Why go:** Unique blend of Japanese and Italian; Michelin-starred; very stylish.
- **Neighborhood:** Chinatown
- **What to expect:** Creative pastas and crudos, excellent cocktails; reservations strongly recommended.
- **Sources:**
  - Michelin Guide: https://guide.michelin.com
  - Official site: https://www.kissatanto.com

---

## Casual & Local Favorites

### 9. **Tacofino (Gastown location)** – Tacos / West Coast Mexican
- **Why go:** Started as a Tofino food truck; now a local staple for tacos and burritos.
- **Neighborhood:** Gastown
- **What to expect:** Casual, good for lunch or a quick dinner; great fish tacos.
- **Sources:**
  - Official site: https://tacofino.com
  - Local lists (e.g., Daily Hive): https://dailyhive.com/vancouver

---

### 10. **Meat & Bread** – Sandwiches
- **Why go:** Famous porchetta sandwich; simple menu done very well.
- **Neighborhood:** Gastown (plus other locations)
- **What to expect:** Fast, counter-service; ideal for a quick, satisfying lunch.
- **Sources:**
  - Official site: https://meatandbread.com
  - Google Maps for hours and locations.

---

### 11. **Nuba** – Lebanese
- **Why go:** Fresh, vibrant Lebanese food; good vegetarian and vegan options.
- **Neighborhoods:** Multiple (Gastown, Kitsilano, Mount Pleasant, Yaletown)
- **What to expect:** Casual but stylish; great for groups and dietary restrictions.
- **Sources:**
  - Official site: https://www.nuba.ca

---

## Seafood & Views

### 12. **Blue Water Cafe** – Seafood
- **Why go:** Longtime benchmark for upscale seafood in Vancouver.
- **Neighborhood:** Yaletown
- **What to expect:** Raw bar, sustainable seafood focus, extensive wine list.
- **Sources:**
  - Official site: https://www.bluewatercafe.net
  - Vancouver Magazine Restaurant Awards: https://www.vanmag.com

---

### 13. **Ancora** – Peruvian–Japanese Seafood
- **Why go:** Nikkei-style seafood with a waterfront setting.
- **Neighborhoods:** False Creek & Ambleside (West Van)
- **What to expect:** Ceviches, sushi, and seafood mains; great patio at the False Creek location.
- **Sources:**
  - Official site: https://www.ancoradining.com

---

## Coffee & Breakfast / Brunch

### 14. **Revolver** – Coffee
- **Why go:** One of the city’s best specialty coffee bars.
- **Neighborhood:** Gastown
- **What to expect:** Rotating roasters, pour-overs, espresso flights.
- **Sources:**
  - Official site: https://revolvercoffee.ca

---

### 15. **Jam Cafe** – Brunch
- **Why go:** Big portions, comfort-food brunch; very popular.
- **Neighborhood:** Beatty St. (near Stadium–Chinatown)
- **What to expect:** Expect a line on weekends; go early or on a weekday.
- **Sources:**
  - Official site: https://jamcafes.com

---

## How to Find What Fits Your Trip

Since you’re coming from Seattle, you might want to prioritize what Vancouver does especially well:

- **Sushi & Japanese:** Miku, Kingyo, Kissa Tanto, Tojo’s  
- **Pacific Northwest / Modern Canadian:** Published on Main, AnnaLena, St. Lawrence  
- **Dim Sum & Chinese:** Dynasty Seafood (or explore Richmond if you have time)

For up‑to‑date rankings and openings/closures, these are reliable, frequently updated sources:

- **Michelin Guide Vancouver:** https://guide.michelin.com  
- **Vancouver Magazine – Best Restaurants:** https://www.vanmag.com  
- **Canada’s 100 Best Restaurants:** https://canadas100best.com  
- **Local food news (Daily Hive Dished):** https://dailyhive.com/vancouver/food

If you tell me your budget, preferred neighborhoods, and whether you’ll have a car, I can narrow this to a short, tailored list plus a 1–2 day eating itinerary.

  - Canada’s 100 Best (often top-ranked):

### 2. **St. Lawrence** – Quebecois / French
- **Why go:** Elevated Quebecois comfort food with French technique; very highly rated nationally.
- **Neighborhood:** Railtown / East of Gastown
- **What to expect:** Rich, hearty dishes (tourtière, pâté, foie gras), intimate room; reservations essential.
- **Sources:**
  - Canada’s 100 Best: https://canadas100best.com
  - Official site: https://stlawrencerestaurant.com

---

### 3. **AnnaLena** – Contemporary Canadian
- **Why go:** Creative tasting menus, playful plating, strong wine pairings; Michelin-starred.
- **Neighborhood:** Kitsilano
- **What to expect:** Refined but relaxed; great for a special night out.
- **Sources:**
  - Michelin Guide Vancouver: https://guide.michelin.com
  - Official site: https://www.annalenayvr.com

---

## Asian & Sushi (Vancouver’s Strongest Category)

### 4. **Miku** – Sushi / Aburi (seared) Omakase
- **Why go:** Famous for aburi (flame-seared) sushi; waterfront views by Canada Place.
- **Neighborhood:** Downtown / Waterfront
- **What to expect:** Polished service, great for lunch or dinner; pricier but consistent.
- **Sources:**
  - Official site: https://mikurestaurant.com
  - Vancouver Magazine review: https://www.vanmag.com

---

### 5. **Tojo’s** – High-End Sushi
- **Why go:** One of Vancouver’s original omakase institutions; chef Tojo is a local legend.
- **Neighborhood:** Fairview (Broadway)
- **What to expect:** Omakase-focused, traditional with some creative twists; expensive but iconic.
- **Sources:**
  - Official site: https://tojos.com
  - Michelin Guide listing: https://guide.michelin.com

---

### 6. **Kingyo** – Izakaya
- **Why go:** Lively Japanese small plates; consistently popular with locals.
- **Neighborhood:** West End (Denman St.)
- **What to expect:** Shared plates, good sake list, energetic atmosphere.
- **Sources:**
  - Official site: https://www.kingyo-izakaya.ca
  - Google Maps reviews for current feedback.

---

### 7. **Dynasty Seafood** – Dim Sum & Cantonese
- **Why go:** One of the city’s go‑to spots for dim sum and banquet-style Cantonese.
- **Neighborhood:** South Granville
- **What to expect:** Classic carts replaced by menu ordering; great seafood and dumplings.
- **Sources:**
  - Vancouver Sun / local coverage: https://vancouversun.com
  - Google Maps / Yelp for recent reviews.

---

### 8. **Kissa Tanto** – Japanese–Italian Fusion
- **Why go:** Unique blend of Japanese and Italian; Michelin-starred; very stylish.
- **Neighborhood:** Chinatown
- **What to expect:** Creative pastas and crudos, excellent cocktails; reservations strongly recommended.
- **Sources:**
  - Michelin Guide: https://guide.michelin.com
  - Official site: https://www.kissatanto.com

---

### 9. **Tacofino (Gastown location)** – Tacos / West Coast Mexican
- **Why go:** Started as a Tofino food truck; now a local staple for tacos and burritos.

---

### 10. **Meat & Bread** – Sandwiches
- **Why go:** Famous porchetta sandwich; simple menu done very well.
- **Neighborhood:** Gastown (plus other locations)
- **What to expect:** Fast, counter-service; ideal for a quick, satisfying lunch.
- **Sources:**
  - Official site: https://meatandbread.com
  - Google Maps for hours and locations.

---

### 11. **Nuba** – Lebanese
- **Why go:** Fresh, vibrant Lebanese food; good vegetarian and vegan options.
- **Neighborhoods:** Multiple (Gastown, Kitsilano, Mount Pleasant, Yaletown)
- **What to expect:** Casual but stylish; great for groups and dietary restrictions.
- **Sources:**

---

## Seafood & Views

### 12. **Blue Water Cafe** – Seafood
- **Why go:** Longtime benchmark for upscale seafood in Vancouver.
- **Neighborhood:** Yaletown
- **What to expect:** Raw bar, sustainable seafood focus, extensive wine list.
- **Sources:**
  - Official site: https://www.bluewatercafe.net
  - Vancouver Magazine Restaurant Awards: https://www.vanmag.com

---

### 13. **Ancora** – Peruvian–Japanese Seafood
- **Why go:** Nikkei-style seafood with a waterfront setting.
- **Neighborhoods:** False Creek & Ambleside (West Van)
- **What to expect:** Ceviches, sushi, and seafood mains; great patio at the False Creek location.
- **Sources:**
  - Official site: https://www.ancoradining.com

---

## Coffee & Breakfast / Brunch

### 14. **Revolver** – Coffee
- **Why go:** One of the city’s best specialty coffee bars.
- **Neighborhood:** Gastown
- **What to expect:** Rotating roasters, pour-overs, espresso flights.
- **Sources:**
  - Official site: https://revolvercoffee.ca

---

### 15. **Jam Cafe** – Brunch
- **Why go:** Big portions, comfort-food brunch; very popular.
- **Neighborhood:** Beatty St. (near Stadium–Chinatown)
- **What to expect:** Expect a line on weekends; go early or on a weekday.
- **Sources:**
  - Official site: https://jamcafes.com

---

---

## 1. Iconic & Fine Dining

### **Published on Main** – Modern Canadian, hyper‑seasonal  
- **Why it’s notable:** Frequently cited as one of Canada’s best restaurants; creative tasting menus, strong wine program, very local/seasonal.  
- **Area:** Mount Pleasant / Main Street  
- **Booking:** Reservations essential.  
- **Sources:**  
  - Canada’s 100 Best (Top 10 in recent lists):  
    https://canadas100best.com

    https://maps.google.com → search “Published on Main Vancouver”

---

### **St. Lawrence** – Quebec‑inspired French  
- **Why:** Rich, classic French‑Québécois dishes; small, intimate room; often booked out.  
- **Area:** Railtown (east of Gastown)  
- **Booking:** Reserve well ahead.  
- **Sources:**  
  - Canada’s 100 Best: https://canadas100best.com  
  - Official site: https://stlawrencerestaurant.com  

---

### **Hawksworth Restaurant** – Contemporary fine dining  
- **Why:** Long‑standing upscale spot in the Rosewood Hotel Georgia; polished service, tasting menus and à la carte.  
- **Area:** Downtown  
- **Sources:**  
  - Official site: https://hawksworthrestaurant.com  
  - Vancouver Magazine Restaurant Awards: https://www.vanmag.com (search “Hawksworth”)

---

### **AnnaLena** – Modern Canadian, inventive  
- **Why:** Creative tasting menus, strong cocktails, relaxed but refined.  
- **Area:** Kitsilano (near Burrard & 1st)  
- **Sources:**  
  - Official site: https://www.annalenayvr.com  
  - Canada’s 100 Best: https://canadas100best.com  

---

## 2. Asian Standouts (Vancouver’s real strength)

### **Miku** – High‑end sushi & aburi (seared)  
- **Why:** Famous for aburi oshi sushi; harbour views; polished but not stuffy.  
- **Area:** Waterfront / Canada Place  
- **Sources:**  
  - Official site: https://mikurestaurant.com  
  - Eater Vancouver overview: https://vancouver.eater.com (search “Miku aburi sushi”)

---

### **Tojo’s** – Sushi institution  
- **Why:** One of the city’s original high‑end sushi counters; omakase focus.  
- **Area:** Fairview (Broadway & Granville area)  
- **Sources:**  
  - Official site: https://tojos.com  
  - Vancouver Sun profile: https://vancouversun.com (search “Tojo’s Restaurant Vancouver”)

---

### **Dynasty Seafood Restaurant** – Dim sum & Cantonese  
- **Why:** Consistently recommended for high‑quality dim sum and banquet‑style seafood.  
- **Area:** West Side (near Oak & 33rd)  
- **Sources:**  
  - Vancouver Magazine “Best Dim Sum” mentions: https://www.vanmag.com  
  - Google Maps reviews: search “Dynasty Seafood Restaurant Vancouver”

---

### **Kissa Tanto** – Japanese‑Italian fusion  
- **Why:** Unique menu, beautiful room, strong cocktails; often on “best of” lists.  
- **Area:** Chinatown  
- **Booking:** Reserve early; small space.  
- **Sources:**  
  - Official site: https://kissatanto.com  
  - Eater Vancouver: https://vancouver.eater.com (search “Kissa Tanto”)

---

### **Phnom Penh** – Cambodian & Vietnamese cult favourite  
- **Why:** Legendary chicken wings and butter beef; casual, always busy.  
- **Area:** Chinatown  
- **Sources:**  
  - Google Maps reviews: search “Phnom Penh Restaurant Vancouver”  
  - Local coverage: https://dailyhive.com (search “Phnom Penh Vancouver wings”)

---

## 3. Casual & Neighbourhood Favourites

### **Tacofino (Gastown location)** – West Coast tacos  
- **Why:** Started as a Tofino food truck; now a local staple for fish tacos, burritos, and good drinks.

---

- **Areas:** Gastown, Kitsilano, Mount Pleasant, etc.  
- **Sources:**  
  - Official site: https://www.nuba.ca  
  - Google Maps reviews: search “Nuba Vancouver”

---

### **Chickpea** – Vegan comfort food  
- **Why:** Very popular plant‑based Middle Eastern‑inspired dishes; big portions, fun vibe.  
- **Area:** Main Street  
- **Sources:**  
  - Official site: https://ilovechickpea.ca  
  - Local reviews: https://scoutmagazine.ca (search “Chickpea Vancouver”)

---

### **The Naam** – Classic vegetarian institution  
- **Why:** One of Vancouver’s oldest veggie spots; casual, hearty, very “Vancouver”.

- **Sources:**  
  - Official site: https://thenaam.com  
  - Google Maps reviews: search “The Naam Vancouver”

- **Why:** Long‑time go‑to for seafood and raw bar; extensive wine list.

- **Sources:**  
  - Official site: https://bluewatercafe.net  
  - Vancouver Magazine awards: https://www.vanmag.com

---

### **Ancora Waterfront Dining & Patio** – Seafood with Peruvian/Japanese touches  
- **Why:** Great views plus refined seafood; two locations.  
- **Areas:** False Creek (near Granville Island) & Ambleside (West Van)  
- **Sources:**

  - Local coffee guides: https://scoutmagazine.ca (search “Revolver coffee”)

---

- **Why:** Excellent coffee plus very good doughnuts; multiple locations.  
- **Areas:** Main Street, Kitsilano, Downtown

---

### **Thomas Haas** – Patisserie & chocolate  
- **Why:** Top‑tier pastries, cakes, and chocolates; worth the trip if you like sweets.

  - Official site: https://thomashaas.com  

---

Because openings/closures and “hot” spots change quickly, it’s worth cross‑checking a few current guides:
